Title: RigNet Aberdeen Foodbank Fundraising Appeal

Description:
A plea for support

At Keighley Salvation Army we work with several individuals and families in need of help with food and toiletries. The food bank has been running for over 20 years and on an average week we would hand out around 30 – 35 parcels. We also support several Asylum seekers and refugees each week with
food, clothing such as school uniforms and travel costs.

However, since the start of the pandemic in 2020 the need for food parcels has grown. Working alongside other food banks and support agencies working in Keighley and the surrounding area well over 2,500 parcels have been delivered or given out. This increase is due to illness, job loss, people isolating, changes to benefits and many other valid reasons why people are struggling and need of support.

As always, our supporters have been very generous with donations of food and money to keep our food bank stocked but we are now beginning to run low on many items.

If you can help us by donating, we would be extremely grateful.

Thank you.

Title: FOODBANK DONATIONS DURING COVID 19

Description:
Every day people in the UK go hungry for reasons ranging from redundancy to receiving an unexpected bill on a low income. A simple box of food makes a big difference, with foodbanks helping prevent crime, housing loss, family breakdown and mental health problems.

We shouldn't need foodbanks in Britain, but we do and so I'm keen to help the Trussell Trust as part of my Booze-free appeal.  People shouldn't be in a position where they can't feed themselves or their children.  Your donations can make a difference to the Trussell Trust's hugely important work.

Did you know?

The Trussell Trust runs a network of over 400 foodbanks, giving emergency food and support to people in crisis across the UK, where thirteen million people live below the poverty line. In the last year they gave 1,182,954 three day emergency food supplies to people in crisis.

Title: Dot Anderson's Birthday (Hamilton Foodbank)

Description:
More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.

Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, its likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.

Were working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that theyre able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.
Title: Saturday night BBO party Foodbank

Description: I have for a while been a supporter of what the Trussell Trust do. I have spent many years in public service and seen and supported vulnerable people experiencing hard times and on many occasions have signposted people to a local food bank for support.I decided to take a big step (if you pardon the pun) and instead of just giving them my money, I figured I would put my best foot forward in the hope it convinced someone else to part with their own money for this great cause. I will be walking a minimum of 18,000 steps per day which is just around 8 miles.Over the course of the month this will mean me doing a minimum of about 200+ miles. This equates to the equivalent, give or take, to completing the Pembrokeshire Coast National Trail. It's the final leg of a 4 month 1000 mile challenge I set myself. Please donate, whatever you can spare and if you can't do that please either promote this page or the work of the Trussell Trust so others can support.Thanks in advance.

Description:
Here at Carpenters, as part of our corporate social responsibility activity, we have been working with our staff to introduce food collection points in all six of our offices across the UK, including three of our offices based in Merseyside.

Once the donations have come in, we then distribute foodbank items to fans Supporting Foodbanks, a joint initiative between Everton (Est. 1878) and Liverpool (Spirit of Shankly) fan clubs and the Charles Thompson Mission in Birkenhead, just two of the wonderful volunteer organisations in the region who are working hard to supply basic provisions to those in need.

Since we started the initiative in September 2017, we have seen many people want to help but are unsure how so we have set up this page for those who wish to donate but we will also include any donations we might receive.

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Title: Arkessa are raising money for Bishops Stortford Foodbank

Description:
Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children.

With the current coronavirus crisis, many vulnerable people are out of work and thus out of food. It's an incredibly challenging time in particular for at-risk communities who rely on the services of foodbanks - and those numbers are set to dramatically increase. Your support will be greatly appreciated.

The Trussell Trust supports a nationwide network of food banks and together we provide emergency food and support to people locked in poverty, and campaign for change to end the need for food banks in the UK.

They are also greatly in need of volunteers at this time, so if you are healthy and able to spare some time, please sign up at: https://www.trusselltrust.org/get-involved/volunteer/
Title: Diana's Supporting UK Foodbanks through Covid-19

Description:
We exist to ensure that no one in Waterloo goes hungry.

For people on low incomes, a sudden crisis  redundancy, benefit delay, illness or even an unexpected bill  can mean going hungry. Every day parents skip meals to feed their children and people are forced to choose between paying the rent or eating.

Since our launch weve given away over 100 tonnes of food to over 12,500 people in need, including almost 5,000 local children.

We are part of The Trussell Trusts UK-wide foodbank network, and together we provide food to thousands of people nationwide every year. The Foodbank is hosted at the Oasis Centre, St Johns Waterloo and St George the Martyr on behalf of South Bank Churches.

We work with local frontline care professionals, such as schools, charities, housing associations, GPs, health visitors and churches, to identify those in need. They distribute vouchers that the client then exchanges for food. When clients arrive at the Foodbank, we offer them the chance to meet with
Title: Oasis Waterloo Foodbank - Covid19 Relief Fund

Description:
The Trussell Trust provides emergency food and
support to people in crisis across the UK, where thirteen million people live
below the poverty line.

This week we will be hosting the first departmental Foodbank
collection of the year, collecting on behalf of the Trussell Trust’s Waterloo
Foodbank.

In addition to the cash donations made on this site, food items from the usual shopping list are being collected in the department. The
Foodbank is also particularly keen to collect items such as mince pies, advent
calendars and Christmas puddings ahead of the Christmas season.

Thank you in advance for your contribution as we continue to support families in crisis in the local community.

FIDS CSR

Description:
When I saw Jeremy Hunt’s tweet thanking Rishi Sunak for donating £50 towards the cost of his £106 lunch I was speechless. He is already worth £12m yet still pocketed the money. It made me both sad and mad in equal measures, but I hope that if folks do get to eat out and receive £10 off their bill, they are able to donate some or all of the saving to the Trussell Trust. At least some good could come of this initiative and be redirected to those that need it most.

Description:
Hello!

We are running a Salteria and Rate Cute GIVEAWAY to raise money for The Trussel Trust Food Banks in the UK. We are Chesterfield based independent brands and wanted to do something good!

We don’t think anyone should have to be left hungry or worry about feeding themselves and their families. Times are pretty stressful at the moment and some families will undoubtably be struggling to find their next meal as they lose their jobs or access to their usual income.

By donating on this page you will be entered into the Giveaway Prize Draw where the lucky winners will receive products from either Salteria or Rate Cute! 💖

Any donation however big or small will help fight the fight against hunger.

Title: Salteria X Rate Cute - Giveaway Fundraiser for UK Foodbank Charity

Description:
As the UK comes to terms with the Coronavirus outbreak what happens to the less fortunate? Over 14 million people in the UK already live in poverty and parts of Greater Manchester have some of the highest child poverty rates in the country. Many thousands of people in our communities already struggle to put food on the table.

Manchester Central Foodbank serve some of the most in need areas in Manchester such as Longsight, Ardwick and East Manchester and are already seeing increased demand due to Coronavirus. Those in insecure work and those already struggling to make ends meet may increasingly need somewhere to turn.

At the same time with localised shortages of some necessities there have been reports of drops in donations to foodbanks. Foodbanks need to replenish supplies themselves with cash donations.

If you feel like you want to do something to help the community during this worrying time please consider donating to Manchester Central Foodbank. £10 could provide a person with food for 3 days.

The foodbank is run by volunteers and all the money raised will go to buy food for those most in need. They intend to remain open to serve the community at this testing time. Lets help them with some donations so they can meet increasing demand.

Description:
﻿The Global Foodbanking Network helps save food waste by donating surplus food to people across the globe that need it the most. Due to a loss of jobs as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak, more people are using food banks. To meet this increased demand, the Network is partnering with local food banks across the world to feed disadvantaged people in over 43 countries.

How can you help?

Here at MUFG, we are holding an EMEA wide Workstation Photo Competition to support charities like the Global Foodbanking Network who are helping the most vulnerable at this time. To join the competition you will need to:

1. Take a photo of your work space.

2. Make a minimum donation of £10 (or the equivalent) to the Global Foodbanking Network.

3. Submit your photo to your local CSR champion.

Your generous donation will support the Global Foodbanking Network will help feed those most in need during these unprecedented times.

﻿For more information please visit www.foodbanking.org


﻿Thank you for all your support!
Title: MUFG's EMEA Photo Competition for The Global Foodbanking Network

Description:
Hi, my name is Paul Pearce, Director & Financial Adviser @ Prudens Financial Protection Ltd.  I’ve been thinking long and hard about how I can support people during the Coronavirus outbreak?  I’ve come to the decision that I’d love to support something local.

Therefore, I’ve decided to set up this Just Giving page to support the amazing work done by the ‘Ormskirk Foodbank Charity’.  Charity No. 1185980.

Due to Coronavirus, it’s been reported there is still extra demand
on food banks and Ormskirk Foodbank are working now to help people in need of these services.  All money raised will go straight to Ormskirk Foodbank Charity account.

So, rather than going to the supermarket and buying extra
food & hygiene products, the best way would be to donate through this page. 

I’m kicking off the support with a donation of £250.00 

I fully understand with so many people being Furloughed by
their own employers, it is a tough time to ask people to donate, but “if” you have a spare £1 or £2, that’s enough to buy some tins of food… so let’s see how much community spirit we have here in Ormskirk and help those who need it most.

Finally, if you are wondering who and how this helps… Ormskirk Foodbank, working with doctors, health visitors, social workers and Citizens Advice, identify the people who need help the most and a foodbank voucher is issued.  The voucher is redeemed and
provides for three days of emergency food.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and stay safe & well.

Paul

Description:
Bearsden West Community Council is proposing that we as a Community set up a foodbank collection point in the local area to serve the Glasgow NW foodbank. Studies have shown that people are more likely to donate food if donation points are local. Currently, there is no collection point in Westerton.

With the introduction of Universal credit to Glasgow by December 2018 resources at centers are becoming stretched. Last year in NW Glasgow alone nearly 9000 people used the foodbank, over 4x the population of Westerton. This is unacceptable in the society we live in.  

Therefore we are asking, especially in the run-up to Christmas, for donations of the following items:

[CLICK HERE FOR SHOPPING LIST] 

For those who would not be able to make food donations we will also be collecting funds which can be donated securely online on this page. 
I hope we as a community can make this a regular thing and we can make this Christmas drive the start of something bigger.

If you have any questions you can contact us at: bwcc@westertonvillage.org.uk or the food bank directly at: info@glasgowNW.foodbank.org.uk


Thanks a million for your support!
Title: Bearsden West Community Council Foodbank Appeal

Description:
Thirteen million people live below the poverty line in the UK, with individuals going hungry every day. 

The Trussell Trust’s 400-strong network of foodbanks provides a minimum of three days’ emergency food and support to people experiencing crisis in the UK. In 2016/17, they gave 1,182,954 three day emergency food supplies to people in crisis.

Intelligent Data have set up a series of charity football matches for transport consultants, local authorities and related industries to generate much needed support for the Trussell Trust.

You dont need to take part in the football matches to donate and all donations no matter how large or small would be greatfully received.

In the lead up to Christmas, please donate to ensure people get the support they need.

Description:
The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity working in 130 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, homeless people, all adult victims of modern slavery and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction.  

During the COVID-19 Pandemic, we have seen unprecedented demand for our Foodbank.  Please help us to help the local community by providing food for those who are unable to supply al that they need.  Thank you.

Description:
Hi all!

It's my birthday in June and, inconveniently for me, the world is on fire.

So instead of buying me a pint, why not chuck a pint's worth of donation to FareShare South West? And if you weren't going to buy me a pint, why not donate anyway? Then reward yourself with a nice pint.

I'm not going to do the spiel about why FareShare South West are so super great, their website does that very well: 

https://fareshare.org.uk/fareshare-centres/south-west/

Suffice to say, if you enjoy food and feel in any way strongly that people should have access to it, you can help make that happen by sending them some money. They do a great job of sending meals to shelters, refugee centres, addiction agencies and loads more. 

Basically, if you send Fareshare money, they will turn that money into FOOD. Incredible.

Description:
This is the next mission for the Footprints for others team. 

People need our help now more than ever before.

Derek Allan will be walking around Druridge Bay Country park for a total of 24 hours to help raise money and food for people in need.

This is taking place on 20th June (The longest Day - Summer Solstice)  10am - 10am 

The footprints for others team will be on site with a table set up to take food donations. This will be at the first carpark on the left as you enter the Country Parks beside the Swan Seat.  (Gate for cars open from 8am - 4.30pm but can still be accessed by foot)

These food donations will be taken to Amble Foodbank and will be distributed to those in need in the local area of Druridge Bay. Any cash donations will go to The Trussell Trust who organise foodbanks nationwide.

**Please note that Social Distancing rules must be adhered to if joining us to making a donation.** 

Amble Foodbanks preferred donations - Pasta, rice, breakfast cereals, tins of meat any kind, meatballs , stew, curry etc, soup, , tins of rice pudding, custard, fruit, tins of veg, potatoes, carrots, peas etc, pasta sauce, cooking oil, toilet rolls, biscuits, diluting juice, shower gel, shampoo soap, wash up liquid . At the moment we have loads of UHT milk, tuna, beans , coffee and tea.  Anything gratefully received. xxx

Title: Louise Hood is fundraising with Tracy's Midnight Runners

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The LUFC Supporters' Trust, through its 'Leeds Fans Food Bank' initiative, supports the Leeds South and East Food Bank and the Leeds North and West Foodbank.  We shouldn't need food banks in 2020, but we do, more than ever. I'm 55 and about 3 stone overweight. I shouldn't need to do 'Couch to 5k' in 2020, but I do, more than ever.

I've been doing this 9 week 'running' challenge and trying to raise funds for this important cause at the same time. It might put some meals on the tables of some people who really need them, and it might help change a few lazy perceptions of football fans and what they care about. It might lower my blood pressure and my cholesterol levels too.

It's actually 11 weeks (icy roads, work and a few aches and pains spread it out) but today I completed the last run of 5k. Going out in some grim weather at times has been made easier knowing kind people are donating to this good cause. This would have been easier in summer...

People supporting this small challenge have donated £575 to support the Leeds Fans Foodbank - I'm very grateful to everyone who contributed. I'll stop seeking further donations in the next day or so.

Thanks to @riotbadger for confirming this was a half-decent idea and to @lufctrust for encouraging me when I asked if it would be possible.
Title: Chris's Couch to 5K for Leeds South and East Foodbank

Description:
At this time of year, the people (and their family and friends) at AkzoNobel in Gateshead usually collect advent calendars and deliver to the Foodbank to distribute to families with children. 

This year, due to the restrictions that COVID-19 brings in terms of not being able to meet to collect calendars, I thought I would encourage you to donate to the foodbank direct to help them at a time when demand has increased significantly. In 2019, the Gateshead Foodbank provided 87 tonnes of goods to families in the area that needed it. By October 2020, they had already exceeded that total and delivered 97 tonnes.

Just £1 can allow the amazing volunteers at the Foodbank to provide an advent calendar for one child. They will also use any donations to help put together hampers so that families who struggle to make ends meet can still put food on the table during the festive season.

Anything you can spare would be amazing and will go a long way to ensuring that those in need get a bit of help towards the end of 2020.

Description:
The communities of Worcestershire have been truly amazing in supporting staff and patients of the Worcestershire hospitals through the coronavirus pandemic. The support has been overwhelming and humbling from cereal bars to hand cream  - it was so appreciated by the staff. The weekly "clap for carers" was so moving each week and really lifted our spirits in very challenging times.

Now we want to thank the communities that supported us,remember colleagues and patients,  and give a little back. We have chosen two charities to support:- the Trussell Trust which gives essential food for those most in need via Worcester foodbank and  Worcestershire Acute Hospitals Charity which provided much needed support during the pandemic by co-ordinating and distributing the 100's of items donated by the public, making sure essential items reached the front line

As non-runners before,this is a challenge.
Title: mel and ed lings page

Description:
More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.

Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, its likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.

Were working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that theyre able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.
Title: clare's South Essex College supporting FE Foodbank Friday

Description:
Zayd and I would like your support to feed the disadvantaged. During these challenging times, more and more families are unable to afford food and the basic necessities. We are fortunate enough to have a fridge full of food and the funds to pop to the grocery store whenever we like - unfortunately not everyone has this luxury!

During these uncertain times, please be generous and help feed the disadvantaged by raising money for food parcels. 

As a community we have a responsibility to help those around us. Zayd and I appreciate all your support and wish you are rewarded for your efforts to help those in need. 

Thank you, 

Zayd and Anam 

"Last  year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. Title: Help us raise money to feed the disadvantaged!

CharityAddress: ATRIUM, THE ORCHARD, WYLAM, NE41 8BS
Description:
During the pandemic I have been finding ways to support and help others using my love of sewing. Initially I made uniform bags and scrubs for my NHS colleagues to keep them safe and then somebody asked me if I could make some face coverings for them to buy. I was happy to make them free of charge, but asked for a donation to a food bank so that others in need could benefit instead. 

Since then I have had numerous requests to make more face coverings and the requests are coming think and fast now that the Government have said that face coverings will be mandatory from 24th July. 

I will be making more over the coming days and will post pictures of the ones available. Due to current demand I am no longer able to make bespoke designs. What you see is what you get - .hope you understand!  If you see one that you would like then please let me know,  make a donation to this page. and I will then make arrangements for get it to you.

Please note  - the face coverings are made from 2 layers of fabric and are not therefore a ‘medical grade’ mask. They are designed to limit the spread of droplets that may transmit COVID 19 and there is no guarantee that they will prevent you from catching the virus from others. They should be washed daily at 60 degrees.  Social distancing and hand washing should still be carried out as per public health guidelines as these are the best methods to prevent infection currently available.

Description:
Every year at Christmas, The Salvation Army in Openshaw provides toys and gifts for families who struggling financially. We recognise that has been a very difficult year for so many people. 

We provide for a number of local families. Much of this is only possible because of the overwhelming generosity of the general public.  Each year we receive donations of toys, food and money and we are  extremely grateful.

Any gift, however small or large will be very much appreciated. Thank you.

The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity working in 130 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, homeless people, all adult victims of modern slavery and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction.

Description:
Tottenham Foodbank helps individuals and families in crisis through the provision of emergency food supplies. The circumstances surrounding a crisis are unique to every individual, so we partner with frontline care professionals, such as health visitors, social workers and other community-based support workers, who are able to identify and refer people facing hunger to the foodbank. As well as receiving nutritionally-balanced 3 day food parcels, people are welcomed with a cup of tea, listened to and signposted to agencies that are able to help resolve the underlying cause of the problem.

Our foodbank was created through a partnership between Freedoms Ark Church and Crutch Haringey, in conjunction with the Trussell Trust. The Trussell Trusts UK foodbank network, last year collected more than 10,000 tonnes of food and gave over 1,084,604 three days food supplies to people in crisis of which over 396,000 went to children.

For more info and for other ways to donate, please visit https
Title: Were raising 1000 to help fund the Tottenham Foodbank

Description:
On Sunday 4th October, I will be running a marathon (26.2 miles) as part of the Luton Lions Weekend of Running in support of Luton Foodbank and Age Concern Luton.

Since the start of Covid-19 pandemic it’s been an extremely challenging time for everyone. The most vulnerable older people and families struggling have been hit the hardest in various way.

The demand on Luton Foodbank has increased as more individuals were furloughed or made redundant during the pandemic. The first week of lockdown was extremely difficult as schools were closed and children receiving free school meals were affected. Food parcels rocketed to over 450 parcels a week during lockdown.

The devastating effects of Covid-19 means that more families than ever before are using the services of the food bank. The last three months have resulted in a huge demand on stocks. This is not sustainable for the Foodbank, which relies on donations from the community in order serve those in need. Luton Foodbank is expecting a dramatic rise in the number of food parcels as the town struggles to deal with the economic impact of the pandemic.

Age Concern Luton have been supporting the most vulnerable and isolated older people in our town since lockdown. Older people and those in ill-health are at highest risk of contracting Coronavirus. The lockdown has resulted in many older people experiencing social isolation and loneliness.

The team of volunteers at Age Concern Luton have been providing essential services such as weekly food parcels, telephone befriending service, housekeeping, laundry, bill-paying, cleaning services as well as support with welfare and benefits to prevent further hardship.

Luton Lions Weekend of Running is in aid of Luton Foodbank and Age Concern Luton. Now, more than ever, both these local charities need our generous support to help families and older people facing such challenging circumstances in our town.

This virtual event will take place on Saturday 3rd (10k and Half Marathon) and Sunday 4th (Marathon) October 2020.

Your contribution will support services that help families in need and care for the most high risk and isolated older people in our town.

Thank you.
Title: Luton Lions Marathon for Luton Foodbank & Age Concern

Description:
Everyone has their lockdown story. All of us will have had our tough times and down days. But for me its all relative.

When people ask how I am coping through the pandemic, I always say the same thing, "Can't complain, I have it better than many."

More and more people are finding hard to make ends meet, heat the house, feed the family and pay the bills. With winter upon us it is more important than ever that we support incredible local initiatives like Morecambe Bay Foodbank, making a real difference to local families, every single day.

I don't want to make this political (even if it is), or lament that we shouldn't need foodbanks (which we shouldn't), those arguments are for another day. Thanks Andy x

Description:
﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿The Coronavirus is already having a hugely negative economic and social impact across the UK, and preventing many vulnerable people from buying the basic items they need.

Glasgow Clyde College wants to engage with our community to help raise awareness and funds to support people through these trying times.

We are working hard to ensure we have a real, positive impact on the lives of our communities.  We have the resources and the fantastic staff and students to make it happen.

That is why we are joining the FE colleges nationally in the FE Foodbank Friday Initiative.  Since the programme started on 20 March, many colleges across the UK are pledging to take part.

As staff and students are now working and studying remotely, it is becoming difficult for staff and students to physically donate items.  That is why we are joining this fundraising campaign, which aims to raise £1,500 so that Glasgow food banks can continue to operate despite social distancing taking place.

We are asking for donations during this very difficult time to ensure we come through the crisis together.  All donations will be shared equally across all four Glasgow Food banks - North East, North West, South East and South West.

Thank-you for your donation.
Title: Glasgow Clyde College supporting FE Foodbank Friday Initiative

CharityAddress: ATRIUM, THE ORCHARD, WYLAM, NE41 8BS
Description:
The global pandemic and periods of national lockdown have been so difficult for families in The Black Country. In my role at Metro Bank I have seen first hand the impact interruption and reductions in income can have on people's ability to put food on the table. The Black Country Food Bank have provided an invaluable lifeline for those in need at this time, and I wanted to do something to help.

At Metro Bank Merry Hill store as lockdown 1 began back in March, we collected donations for the food bank in our banking hall and had an incredible response from our customers. Right across the Black Country individuals and businesses have been so supportive of the Food Bank in terms of food donations, but this time round in lockdown 2 I have decided instead to set myself a personal challenge to raise some physical cash to support the administration and overheads incurred in the logistics of providing this vital service.

I've set a modest fundraising target which I'm hoping to exceed, and I'm also looking forward to the inevitable health and well-being benefits that training for and cycling 40 miles will bring.

40 miles may not sound like much. Keen amateur cyclists regularly smash 40 miles on road bikes on a Sunday morning. This challenge however will be completed on a much heavier mountain bike, along the winding, muddy, dark and at some points downright treacherous canal towpaths of the Black Country. I will be completing a loop from Metro Bank Merry Hill store, joining the canal at the delph locks and winding my way through Stourbridge, Kinver, Wombourne, Tettenhall and finally by road to Wolverhampton Metro Bank Store around lunch time. After some much needed sustenance and a quick photo opp, it will be back on the bike and back on the canal following the railway route through Coseley, Tipton and Dudley Port before making a sharp right towards Merry Hill and completing the loop.  The final leg includes a spooky two mile ride through the infamous Netherton Canal Tunnel, not for the faint of heart, and with weary legs I'm hoping to be back at Merry Hill by night fall.  This is very much a "couch to..." challenge for me, so any support both moral and financial will be much appreciated.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Title: Cafe Crawl for the Foodbank TEXT  TRUS61  (POUNDS)n to 70070

Description:
Dear all,

In 2008 when I started working for the RDS I had no idea that I would stay for this long. Two kids and PhD later, I have quite literally grown up with this job!

As some of you know, we are emigrating to Kuala Lumpur at the end of July. 

So, here we are, nearly 12 years on, and almost the last 17 weeks have been in lockdown! It’s fair to say there will be no party. I feel sad that I won’t get a chance to say a proper goodbye to so many of you. Under any ‘normal’ circumstances, I would be planning an epic party to mark my leaving from the RDS EM but this is not going to be possible and the thought of a Locktini on Zoom fills me with cringing awkwardness 

So, I would like to ask for your help instead so here’s my story…

Since lockdown one thing that has helped me to retain my sanity and happiness (whilst home schooling a 4 and 7 year old and working) is cooking and eating with my family. I believe that food influences our moods, our physical recovery and brings a focus to the day.

But whilst I have been enjoying delicious homemade food, I have also been reflecting on how privileged I am to buy the ingredients I need and have heating facilities to cook food with. My eyes have been opened even more since I started volunteering in March at a local foodbank in Leicester. I help, with other volunteers, to make food and sanitation parcels.

So many families have been struck further into food poverty since COVID-19. 

This foodbank like many others relies solely on donations from Fareshare, the goodwill of community leaders and local people, so that local families don’t go hungry. 

It’s been thoroughly enjoyable and inspiring working with you all. I’ve learned so much and leave with very happy memories. My last working day is the 8th July. 

Please keep in touch, add me to your LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/in/raksha-pandya-wood-79204733 or just drop me an email: rpandyawood@gmail.com

Take care and stay safe

Raksha Pandya-Wood

Description:
Horsham Ladies Rugby Team LOVE to know what’s for dinner, in fact our players will often ask their opposition this question when in a scrum! Our training has been cancelled during Lockdown #2, so we have decided to use this time to help those who don’t know where their next meal is coming from. We are raising money for the Horsham Food Bank c/o Horsham Matters. 

We have pledged as a team to cover the official distance from Land's End to John O Groats, 874 miles, during the 4 weeks of lockdown. We will be walking, running, cycling, horse riding, swimming, and logging our progress along the way. 

Please support this fabulous charity and sponsor us. 

Just lately, Horsham District Foodbank has had many conversations with those who have just been made redundant, were not entitled to redundancy pay and are struggling to make ends meet. These are difficult times and as UK employment continues to fall by the biggest amount in over a decade, there is worse to come, and for some time to come.The average cost of a emergency food parcel of 3 day's food is £15 for one person for long-life food only. Supplemented by donated fresh food, this makes such a difference for someone with no money to buy groceries. Demand has risen by 100% and every penny donated will support someone who needs it, in our local community.
Title: Horsham Ladies Rugby Team Lands End to John O Groats

Title: Connect 2's C2C Company Raffle

Description:
Thank you to everyone who has donated to this campaign, without the support of so many of you we would not have been able to continue, launch new sites and ultimately address the immediate food crisis caused by coronavirus.

As the coronavirus crisis has continued, we have experienced a huge increase in need. To illustrate this, prior to the crisis our busiest week was in December 2019, where we supported 117 individuals and families across four foodbanks.  In the last week of April 2020, just one of our seven foodbanks supported 126 individuals and families. This increase in need means our weekly food bill would be almost £8,000, should we need to purchase it, not to mention staffing, transport and equipment.  

Sadly, we are expecting this increased need to continue for the foreseeable future as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences.  We still don’t think anyone in our community should have to face going hungry. That’s why we asking you to support us to continue to provide three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food to local people, in the initial crisis, through 2020 and beyond!

Sometimes the numbers involved can seem daunting so we’ll make it simple - £27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three.

Thank so much for all your support, love and encouragement – S6 foodbank!
Title: Hallam CC Food Bank Appeal

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The challenge the 6th Form boarders at West Buckland School are going to undertake, is to get an exercise bike and cycle Lands' end to John O'Groats (874 miles). The boarders and staff will take on this massive task, starting on Friday 27th until we complete the epic 874miles.

The charity we would love to do it for is the Northern Devon foodbank. We all know food banks have been in the news recently because of Covid. The amount of people using them now has risen sharply over the last year.

In 2019/20 approximately 1.9 million people used a foodbank in the United Kingdom, around 300 thousand more than the previous year. 

Along with that, we have investigated it and the stats are shocking and quite upsetting.

Almost a fifth of UK homes with children have been struggling to access food in the past five weeks, the Food Foundation says.

As the outbreak spread, food banks in the Independent Food Aid Network (IFAN) saw the need for food parcels rocket, reporting an average 59 per cent rise in need from February to March – 17 times higher than this time last year.

Hilary Croft, CEO of The Felix Project, said: “We wanted to have a more direct impact on children as we know of the consequences of children going hungry.

“They lose an hour of learning time a day, they can’t concentrate, it’s just huge lost potential.”    ​This is so powerful when you think about it.

It's never the Children's fault but they will live with the trauma their whole lives and no child should NEVER EVER GO HUNGRY.

So with your help, we want to raise as much money as we can for this great cause in this uncertain time for lots of Families.

Every £1 donated will ensure a school child and their family has the food needed for a nutritious meal.

So Please Donate!!!!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Title: Parker's Boarding challenge Lands' end to John O'Groats (874 miles)

Description:
﻿﻿﻿This Autumn 2016 the UK Purchasing Diversity Committee are collaborating with the Trussell Trust Food Bank as part of Ford's Global Week of Caring.

 I will be collecting food donations through this Autumn beginning in September. This Just Giving page will collect any monetary donations people wish to make. For those people wishing to make actual food donations, I will be taking those at my desk and delivering them to the local Basildon food bank to support the local area to Dunton.

Please be aware that today people across the UK will struggle to feed themselves and their families. Redundancy, illness, benefit delay, domestic violence, debt, family breakdown and paying for the additional costs of heating during the winter months are just some of the reasons why people go hungry.

Your donations will have an immediate impact and help to assist people who are suffering a food crisis. Please be aware that your contributions will directly stop local people going hungry.﻿

Description:
I believe that MPs are elected to speak for the people, but our MPs do not seem to be listening. Poverty can affect anyone, and in a time of national crisis such as this pandemic it is affecting more and more families.

Last year, food banks in The Trussell network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. This was before Covid-19.

MPs are paid £80k per year, it has been reported they are to receive a £3k payrise, they claim expenses and on top of this they can earn money through consultancy work and other jobs - but the people they are paid to represent are struggling.

The premise of this campaign is simple:

  • Donate just £2 to The Trussell Trust to support their national food bank network and provide food to those in need.
  • By donating you are sending a message to our MPs that they do not speak for me, every donation is your voice to make them listen.
  • If you feel able to donate more, it is up to you.

It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can support food banks, and as a nation, tell our MPs that we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

https://www.trusselltrust.org/

https://www.parliament.uk/about/mps-and-lords/members/pay-mps/

https://fullfact.org/economy/poverty-uk-guide-facts-and-figures/

https://www.endchildpoverty.org.uk/
Title: They do not speak for me

Description:
Christmas can be a difficult time of year for families, and especially due to the current global pandemic and the various lockdowns and furlough schemes.  So instead of running a Secret Santa this year, I am suggesting that if you would normally join a Secret Santa Scheme, donate what you would normally spend on Secret Santa to a local cause.  I have chosen Stockport Foodbank to support our local community.  Stockport Foodbank operates from six centres across Stockport, providing food to people in crisis.

Your donations are obviously optional and can be anonymous and for any amount, and don't forget to add Gift Aid.
Title: Simon's Chistmas Secret Santa

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We recently attended and Anti Poverty evening in Kirkcaldy and I was shocked to find out that Kirkcaldy foodbank alone spend £8000 per month on food! Run by 100 volunteers. More than one third of those who receive support from Kirkcaldy foodbank are children. 8650 food parcels per month are given out from Kirkcaldy foodbank. These figures left me feeling very sad and that I wanted to do something to help.

I know many of us have our kitchen cupboards packed so full that if we simply cleared away the tins of soup we aren't going to use, the pasta packets that we have 4 of along with the excess boxes of cereal we have never looked at. That we together could help these people and help Kirkcaldy foodbank, even if its a drop in the ocean for them.

That is why I am asking you all to please donate £5 worth of food from your cupboards, or £5 from your purse/ wallet.

In return, your name will be entered into our draw to win a kitchen deep clean inc oven clean to the value of £80. Once the draw ends I will pull one name from a hat and that lucky winner will receive this offer. You can enter as many times as you like. So go on, have that kitchen clear out and see just how much you have that can be donated, I bet its a lot more than you think!!!

Thank you in advance,

Cara and all the team at Domestic Matters x

Title: Mark's Dry July

Description:
Donate via this page to support The Trussell Trust food banks. Donations made on this page are counted to the #RyburnHelpFromHome fundraising total, and lead to teachers doing silly things for your entertainment.

Visit www.justgiving.com/team/ryburn to find out more about our fundraiser. 

Why donate to The Trussell Trust?

More and more people are being forced to food banks because there’s nowhere else for them to turn. Last year the food banks in our network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food supplies to people in crisis and over 500,000 of these went to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year. 

As the Coronavirus outbreak develops, more people than ever could need our help. 

Your generous support means food banks will be able to continue to provide the lifeline of emergency food to people in crisis.

We’re doing all we can to support food banks at this time. Your support means that we can:

  • Offer additional support, funding, partnerships and guidance to food banks to help them adapt and continue to provide support to people during this challenging time
  • Prepare to support food banks after the immediate crisis has passed. When the pandemic passes, we’ll be working with food banks to help people in communities across the country with issues that have arisen as a result of the pandemic, and also supporting food banks to work towards a future where their food bank is no longer needed in that community
  • Step up our work to tackle the structural reasons behind people needing food banks, so we can move towards a future where that help isn’t needed – this includes funding ground breaking research, campaigns and work with policy makers to find and make the changes needed to ensure we all have enough money for the essentials.
Title: Ryburn's Help From Home

Description:
The Coronavirus is already having a hugely negative economic and social impact across the UK, whether that’s job uncertainty or self-isolation preventing many vulnerable people from buying the basic items they need.

As an education provider Loughborough College wants to engage with our community to help raise awareness and funds to help people through these trying times.

We are working hard to ensure we have a real, positive impact on the lives of our local communities. We have the resources and the fantastic staff to help make it happen.

That is why we are joining FE colleges nationally in the FE Food Bank Friday initiative. Since the programme started on Friday 20 March many colleges across the country are pledging to take part.

As staff and students are now working and studying remotely, it is becoming difficult for staff and students to physically donate any items. That is why we have joined this fundraising campaign, which aims to raise £2,000 so that foodbanks can continue to operate despite social distancing taking place across the country.

We are asking anyone willing during this extremely tough period to consider donating what they can to ensure that we all can pull through this crisis together.

Thank you so much for your kind donation.


About The Trussell Trust

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. It’s not right that people can’t afford the basics. With your help, we can help end the need for food banks. As a nation, we expect no one should be left hungry or destitute. Illness, disability, family breakdown or the loss of a job can happen to any of us. With your help #ThisCanChange

Dros y flwyddyn dwetha ma 1,583,668 o barseli bwyd wedi gal eu rhoi allan, gyda dros hanner miliwn (577,618) o rhain i blant. Llynedd nath y Banc Bwyd yng Nghaerdydd rhoi allan 13,248 parsel bwyd a ma angen pob help arnyn nhw. Helpwch plis. Rhowch be chi gallu. Ma teuluoedd allan yna yn ddibynnol ar hyn. Rhaid ni dynnu at ein gilydd a helpu pawb trwy’r amseroedd anodd yma.

Over the past five years the number that depend on Food Banks in the UK have risen by 73% (Trussel Trust). Over the past year 1,583,668 food parcels have been issued, with over half a million (577,618) of these for children. Last year the Food Bank in Cardiff handed out 13,248 food parcels and continue to need every help. Please help. Give what you can. Families out there are dependent on this. We must pull together and help everyone through these difficult times.

Description:
One of my friends is turning 50 this week and instead of receiving presents, has asked us to give £10 in an act of kindness to someone else and make their day. 

Another of my friends, for her job, has just carried out extensive research about food banks in Surrey. There are over 30 now, in an area that is better off than in many places in the UK. And the people using them are people who are working. Imagine getting home from the office and not being able to afford to eat. I am giving the £10 my 50-something friend has given me for others to The Trussell Trust who run the food banks here, but please would you also give something too? I am going to fast for 24 hours to incentivise you! Thank you for helping.

Description:
We are fortunate that the majority of our TalkTalk colleagues are provided with the tools, flexibility and support to be able to work from home during this crisis.

Foodbanks will be supporting many families and individuals through the coming weeks and possibly months. 

This will undoubtedly put a further strain on these services. There is less footfall in supermarkets, resulting in fewer donations at foodbank collection points. Many children rely upon school meals to obtain their primary nourishment. The school closures will result in more people approaching foodbanks for assistance.

If you can support this service by donating what you would normally spend on a days commute or your morning coffee, this will add up and could be the difference between a family eating or going without.

I will be adding a donation on a week by week basis as long as this continues.

If you are able to donate, please don't forget to add gift aid!

Thank you.

The Brick's aim is to eradicate homelessness and poverty in our community. They support homeless people, those facing homelessness, and people experiencing crisis or poverty in the Wigan borough. People who are marginalised by society, who can, with support, become independent and contribute positively to their communities. Services include crisis intervention, housing and health support on behalf of the Council, a foodbank, social and employment training, and wide-ranging volunteering opportunities. Description:
"The foodbank was there when we needed it most , it was an absolute lifeline" - Sheffield S6 Foodbank recipient

"We don't think anyone in the community should have to face going hungry. That's why we provide three days' nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to us in crisis. We are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by the Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK." - Sheffield S6 Foodbank

The S6 Foodbank helps an incredible 700 Sheffield families each week. They are aiming to raise £40,000 which will release a further £40,000 match funding from the government via the 'Love Your Neighbour' Partnership. All monies raising will go directly to buy food for the foodbank.

My challenge is to run 400 kms from 25th October to Christmas Day with the aim of raising £400 towards the Sheffield S6 Foodbank £40k for £40k appeal.

I hope that you will sponsor me so that together we can contribute to helping the people of Sheffield who, for whatever reason, are at present struggling to feed their families.
Title: Run 400 kms to raise 400 pounds for Sheffield Foodbank's 40k for 40k appeal

Description:
This year has seen an 89% increase in need for emergency food parcels, 107% increase in parcels going to children.

The number of families with children receiving food parcels has almost doubled compared to last year. 

Many foodbanks are struggling to meet the demand.

Pay it forward this pay day and donate your lunch money to help the foodbanks. A McDonalds will cost you about £6, for a few pounds more foodbanks can supply a healthy, nutritionally balanced food box that will last an individual 3 days. Let's #dosomethingfornothing NO2. 🥰
Title: Geez yer lunch money.

Description:
Over the next few months, I’ll be cycling 2033km with 32448m of vertical climbing...but to maintain social distancing, I’ll be doing it all in my garage. 

Yup, I’ll be ticking off every Zwift route available, leading up to my final ride, riding the full length of the Prudential Ride London route - 173km long and 2496m up - in one go.

I’d already done 400km before I started this, but there’s still plenty to go. You can follow my progress here, on Strava, or on my social media accounts @thatcastrochap. I’ll also be streaming some of the longer rides, so that should be a laugh. Come and watch me suffer.


— — —

Title: Tour de Garage

Description:
Lockdown Languages was initially created when the schools closed in mid-March and I wondered if I could put my Modern Languages degree in French and Spanish to any use.  I started off by offering to help friends’ kids with their home lessons. 

Since then, Lockdown Languages has taken a few twists and turns and I’m now also doing basic classes for adults and some boozy Zooms with groups who just want to learn a few words and have some fun.  I can manage very basic Italian too!   

There are also collaborative classes with friends whose skills are on a par with mine where we all prepare a short written piece to read and discuss new words and grammar.  

There are no fees.   Frankly, I’m not qualified and extremely rusty.  But if there’s a way of raising a little bit of money through this that would be amazing.  So if you’ve enjoyed a class,  or have no interest in taking part but think the concept is fun, I would be delighted if you could chip in a little bit to support Foodbanks through the Trussell Trust.   Thank you, merci, gracias xx

Description:
For those who know me, I currently get very little sleep. This means I have come to rely heavily on chocolate and other delicious treats, just to get me through the day (alas, i don't like coffee, otherwise I'd be all over it!). 

My chocolate reliance has gotten a little out of hand and last week I ate so much I got a bit jittery and shaky. Definitely time to do something to combat my greediness and adopt a more healthy diet. And i thought, why not give up chocolate and do something more positive with my personal challenge? Raising money for the local food bank and being less of a greedy guts makes perfect sense to me.

Here's to raising money for those in need and for (hopefully) reducing my risk of an extra chin and flab role and diabetes!

Title: Patrick is Living Below the Line

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Short version: £25 from 100 people, helps 100 families in their time of need. Just donating what you can AND also sharing this page can make a huge difference. I'll be living on £1/day for 6 days at the end of July.

Live Below The Line

Live below the line is a challenge from The Hunger Project. It is quite simply - live below the line for a given time period. Sometimes a day, sometimes 5.

The aim is to raise awareness of extreme poverty abroad, nationally and at home, and to raise funds.

The line is the world extreme poverty line, below which 1.2 billion people live. That's a mind boggling number. The line is £1 a day. £1 a day for food - all your food for one day.

Bringing closer to home: 13 million people live in poverty in the UK. 600,000 of those live in Greater Manchester - 1 in 4 people. 3.9 million children in the UK live in poverty. 91,000 of those are children - the majority have 1 or more parents in work.

These are the people that access foodbanks - over 1 million times in the past year. 1 million times when someone would go hungry instead.

They do this week in, week out, unrelentingly.

6 pounds, 6 days

As a result, I will live below the line for 6 days. That's the 5 days people normally do, with a day on top. I'll be doing this from Sunday 23rd July 2017 to Friday 28th July 2017.

Why Manchester Food Bank

It's on our doorstep. It's personal. 1 in 4 people in manchester are in poverty. No-one chooses poverty - poverty chooses them. Manchester Food Bank was seeded by the Trussel Trust, and supported by them as part of their national collective of foodbanks. 

Why am I doing this?

I'm doing this because I think modern society should be able to exist without people living on the borders of starvation. Many years ago I had to live on a similar budget to this, but I think things have become worse. I was lucky enough to be able to use education to lift myself out of that. Many people are not lucky enough to do that. In the absence of change, they need assistance.

I feel strongly that foodbanks should not need to exist, and that they are a failure of society. Until they're no longer needed, those using foodbanks need help.

Lastly, it's in essence to raise awareness and to try and do something positive that I couldn't do myself.

Why such a high target?

Because it matters. I've picked a figure that is achievable and would make a difference. Yes, it's a hard target, but if I get 1/2 way there I will have succeeded. Every level of support helps. Some baseline numbers: £10 buys a basket of food for an emergency food parcel, £25 buys a family 3 days of food. (£2/day is not luxury), £50 restocks supplies on the things the food back runs short of for 1 week

Which ever way you look at it, the target makes a difference.

  • Helps 100 families over a difficult period. Just 100 families. On average 400 people.?
  • Or it helps 250 people in a period of emergency
  • Or it helps the foodbank for a whole year to not worry about things they run short of.

No matter the actual amount raised though, it makes a difference.

Bear in mind:

  • How much do you spend on entertainment a week / a month? Can you go without that once?
  • Rather than a take away, can you cook at home instead?
  • If you're contemplating a new gadget, can you wait a month and instead donate 1/12th the cost?
  • As little as £1 helps, that seems like a little, but it can /literally/ be a day's food for someone.

You might not be in a position to help financially. I get that.

  • If you can't give, please share this page, this helps. Each time you share this page, you increase the chances of another £10 towards the goal.
  • Failing that, please add foods to a collection point. It goes directly to helping the same foodbanks.

Gift Aid

Please, PLEASE, please gift aid your donation if you can. It boosts the intake. it means that every £20 donated raises £25 for the charity - with the extra £5 coming from taxes you already pay - forcing the govt to do a tiny fraction of their part too.

Donate via text

You can also donate via mobile phone. Examples:
  • If you want to donate 5 days' food - £10 - you do this by texting "MCFB75 £10" to 70070
  • If you want to donate a day's food - £2 - you do this by texting "MCFB75 £2" to 70070

Practicalities

I'll track my progress here: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/sparkslabs . I'll provide proof of costs here as well. The key practicality is that you can only eat foods you buy that week.

One common/small exception I've noticed is people allow themselves salt and pepper. (Since you buy those very very rarely, and use fractions of a penny if that if anything) But no spices, *nothing* else you might take for granted.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Title: Help me help Manchester Foodbank Help 100 Families by living below the line

Hi Guys,

Starting today, I have decided that over the course of the next 30 days I will run 100 miles. In order to raise money and support, for the Black Country food bank. I have thought about doing this challenge before however I have always found an excuse not to pursue it. Well not this time I'm 100% determined to complete this challenge and raise money for the Black Country food bank.

More people are seeking help from their local food banks to help provide food for either an individual or families. The Black Country food bank not only provides food but also toiletries, sanitary products, house hold cleaning products and nappies for people requiring this support. Unfortunately there will be  many more job losses and people being furloughed, in this coming period. Causing major financial implications  for many people. Jenna x

Description:
The Coronavirus is already having a hugely negative economic and social impact across the UK, whether that’s job uncertainty or self-isolation preventing many vulnerable people from buying the basic items they need.

As an education provider Bournemouth & Poole College wants to engage with our community to help raise awareness and funds to help people through these trying times.

We are working hard to ensure we have a real, positive impact on the lives of our local communities. We have the resources and the fantastic staff to help make it happen.

That is why we are joining FE colleges nationally in the FE Food Bank Friday initiative. Since the programme started on Friday 20 March many colleges across the country are pledging to take part.

As staff and students are now working and studying remotely, it is becoming difficult for staff and students to physically donate any items. That is why we have joined this fundraising campaign, which aims to raise £2,000 so that foodbanks can continue to operate despite social distancing taking place across the country.

About The Trussell Trust

Last year, food banks in our network provided more than 1.6 million emergency food parcels to people in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children. Description: The last few months have seen immense suffering and hardship from storms and flooding. However the outbreak of the Coronavirus has quite literally changed everyones lives and turned society upside down.However, The Salvation Army is resolute and strong and just as we did in the Spanish Flu pandemic, and during the bombing and the Blitz we will carry on, doing what we can to support people and communities in the ways that we can, within the Government guidelines.In true Salvation Army Spirit, our greatest strength is our flexible, responsive local presence. Right now, each of our 650 corps and community centres will know exactly what the most effective things are to do. We are not just responding to the virus impact in one or two ways, but dozens and dozens of different ways, from food banks to counselling, from supporting NHS isolation units to checking up on people who are living alone. In Carnforth we have chosen to work alongside existing support networks to support and protect our Community. Please give what you can to enable us to help as many people as possible!
Title: Carnforth Corps & Community 's Carnforth COVID Response

Description:
Sandra, or Mum to me (or Nana, Sister Bray and more often than not "Gobshite"), recently lost her brave battle with cancer. A battle that she faced with her characteristic no-nonsense attitude, an unyielding desire to win, and above all her sense of humor.

Since her passing on 14th November our family have received an
overwhelming level of love and support for Mum. It’s so humbling to know how much she means to so many people.

In lieu of flowers and in her memory, Mum requested that donations be made to St Francis Church foodbank – Ran by The Trussell Trust which runs a network of over 400 foodbanks, giving emergency food and support to people in crisis across the UK.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - the family raises more in Mum's memory, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Mum was adamant her legacy should be something positive and so picked this local charity to support, she wanted to make a difference to people in need… and we all know she always gets her way. :)

Sarah (the good child) x
Title: In loving memory of Sandra Bray

Title: Give up your festive Latte for Trussell Trust

Description:
In the
UK, more than 14 million people are living in poverty – including 4.5 million
children. We support more than 1,200 food bank centres in the UK to provide a
minimum of three days’ nutritionally-balanced emergency food to people who have
been referred in crisis, as well as support to help people resolve the crises
they face. Between April 2018 and March 2019, food banks in our network
provided a record 1.6 million food supplies to people in crisis, a 19%
increase on the previous year.

At the moment people have enough to lose
sleep over without worrying where their next meal is coming from and how they
are going to feed their families.  As you
have probably seen on the news, some NHS staff are having to rely on foodbanks,
this in itself shouldn’t be happening but that’s a discussion for another day.

By donating you will be supporting the
UK’s most vulnerable people and some of the incredible staff in our NHS during
this pandemic and lord knows we need to be pulling together now more than ever.  Please give as much or as little as you can
to this wondrous charity.

Description:
The communities of Worcestershire have been truly amazing in supporting staff and patients of the Worcestershire hospitals through the coronavirus pandemic. The support has been overwhelming and humbling from cereal bars to hand cream and everything in between - it was so appreciated by the staff. The weekly "clap for carers" was so moving each week and really lifted our spirits in very challenging times.

Now we want to thank the communities that supported us and give a little back. We have chosen two charities to support:

- the Trussell Trust which gives essential support for those most in need

Title: HELEN's Dry January

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

When I came across the work that Little Village do I was stunned. It’s like a foodbank, but instead of food, it offers essential items like clothing, books, toys and baby equipment to parents in need, right across London. It’s frankly alarming that thousands of families need to rely on ‘hand me downs’ and the good will of other people to barely survive. This is just for essential items. I am saddened that in this day and age tiny babies and children under 5 are going without the most basic of items right here in London, items I completely took for granted when I was pregnant and during the early years of my children growing up. 

Can you imagine trying to breastfeed your little one without any breast pads to pop in after? Or not having enough nappies? Imagine not being able to clothe your children appropriately. Imagine trying to entertain your smallest children without the most basic of toys or books? 

This is where I think I can make a small difference. As part of my ongoing #asyouaremotherhood campaign across Instagram and Facebook, I'm celebrating and highlighting those of us (silent) women heroes, who everyday, do all we can to provide for our children and to be the best mothers we can be.

There is such a pressure for us mums to be perfect: we all strive for perfection everyday when the reality is, perfection doesn't exist.

We all worry, are anxious about whether we're doing the right thing for our unborn baby or the children we already have. We can look at others and think they're somehow doing it better than us, and feel like we've failed.

We must change our attitudes and change the way we treat ourselves.

That's why I'm giving away a limited number of mother and baby photoshoots to celebrate how amazing and unique we are as mothers, how we ARE doing all we can to help our children. 

And that our best is good enough. We are good enough.

Through this project, I can ask pregnant women and mums to come into my studio, get a fabulous photoshoot to show how fabulous they are (just as they are without the need for fancy or OTT props) - and spread the word about self-love and acceptance. 

And then in return all I'd ask is a contribution to Little Village.

This is my way to give back to some struggling families on my own doorstep? Little Village does just that; giving the gift of the most basic but essential things to babies and children who really need them. 

As their website says: “It takes a village to raise a child - this is especially true in London where we often feel alone as parents.

“Little Village is a gift from one family to another, passed on with love.”

If I ask each of my photography clients to donate, say, just £20 to this cause, I would forgo my booking fee of usually £95. Clients could of course donate more if they wish or were able to, but I thought this would be an excellent start. 

So if you're keen to book a Maternity or Baby photoshoot with me, I’ll direct you to this page where you can donate what you can and then we’ll see what happens. Things will snowball from there. Let’s do this together and be part of something hopeful to change the world we live in, right on our doorsteps.

Title: 24 hour fast

Description:
Last year I was unfortunately diagnosed with cancer. Whilst receiving Chemotherapy, I was feeling sorry for myself and was bored with feeling tired and yukky all the time. It was then I came up with an idea.

I decided to have a get better list. NOT a bucket list because a bucket list is things to do before you die, but I am planning to be around for a long time yet. Anyway, for every chemo treatment I have added an activity. They are all quite crazy things such as indoor sky diving; trampoline Parks; Go Ape etc. You get the sort of idea

The next event is taking place on Saturday the 9th June. My daughter has bought the family and I a very strange experience. We are going to be flung off the Killiecrankie bridge on a Bungee Swing. I told her that I was no longer scared of anything but really?!?

Well here is where you come in. I thought while doing this it may be a good idea to raise money for a good cause. I am hoping to raise money for The Storehouse Foodbank, which is run by the Falkirk VIneyard Church. This is a very important charity and very close to my heart. It seeks to help disadvantaged families in our local areas by providing them with food and other essentials in a time of crisis. If you feel you could contribute anything then I wold be really grateful and it may give the extra incentive to fly off the bridge.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and thank you for your generosity.

With lots of love

Michelle
Title: Michelle's Bungee Swing

Growing up I have always been complimented about my hair and have used it as a security blanket for myself. I hope that by raising money for the foodbank I can provide some security in these difficult times for those most in need. It doesn't matter how much you give every little helps.

Description:
#NoChildHungry

This half term, Transforming Exercise & Nutrition LTD want to do our bit to help 🖤

There are many local children who will be going hungry this half term, since the Government is no longer providing vouchers for children in poverty for free school meals during school holidays...

So, our TEN coaches and many of our TEN participants will be taking part in a 450 burpee challenge from Monday 26th October - Sunday 1st November! 

That’s 1 burpee for every child registered with Colchester Food Bank!

We are doing this with the aim to try and raise £450 in total for Colchester FoodBank and to also encourage local people to donate some much needed food to the charity 💫

Did you know that a third of those in crisis that Colchester FoodBank feeds are children? 2020 has already been their busiest year ever. 

As Colchester's Bishop Roger Morris from the Diocese of Chelmsford says in his keynote speech, child poverty should already be history. No child in our nation should be starving. 

Here’s the details of Colchester FoodBank’s website, if you’d like to drop off a food parcel in place of a sponsorship:

https://colchester.foodbank.org.uk/

Finally, please do ask your MPs to help and if possible sign the petition asking the Government to support vulnerable children; #endchildfoodpoverty by implementing 3 recommendations from the National Food Strategy to expand access to Free School Meals, provide meals; activities during holidays to stop holiday hunger; increase the value of and expand the Healthy Start scheme.

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/554276

Thank you everyone 🖤🚀

- Amy & The TEN Team

Description:
This fundraising page is something we as a family have wanted to do for quite some time. With the Covid pandemic hitting the world in 2020 it has caused us to reflect even more so on how many things we are so very blessed to receive at Christmas time, but perhaps don't "need". We are struck when we look around us at so many other people who are in much more need than us. 

Therefore, rather than receiving an overwhelming amount of lovely gifts at Christmas this year, we would instead like to invite our friends and family to donate to Leeds South & East Foodbank who are partnered with The Trussell Trust to further their works in providing meals to local people who are in crisis. Supporting a local Foodbank is something we feel strongly and passionately about as we believe this will make a much bigger difference in not just ours but other people's lives and in general, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. 

If you could kindly donate any amount of money you might have spent on us this Christmas to our chosen charity instead, this will go a long way and mean the world to us this Christmas time. We ourselves as a family will too be contributing and would like to thank you for taking the time to read this and help out where you can. If you would like to learn more about the charity, you can click on their icon above which will take you to their page.

Last but not least, Merry Christmas from the Kwoks.

Title: MQ Christmas 2020 Greenwich food bank appeal

Description:
In the last few years a December donation for our local food bank has became an office tradition. Last year each team across the office donated a (very generous) box of goods and the total amount of food took hours and numerous car trips to transport to the food bank warehouse!

This year is more challenging due to working from home and the restrictions we are all having to live with. Sadly also, the pandemic has seen a vastly increased number of people needing to use the food banks services due to COVID and the subsequent effect on jobs and the economy, with the North East continuing to be hit hard with no end yet in sight. Therefore it is really important we find a way to support them, and an online cash donation is the easiest way to do this, meaning the food bank can use this money to buy goods to give directly to their clients.

We would love to hit the £1000 mark, which works out under £5 per person across the office, so we are asking everyone to contribute £5 or whatever you can afford. Remember to add Gift aid too!

Description:
From Thursday 24th September until Sunday November 1st, I'm going to try and run a total of 170 miles around the High Peak. That's an average of 8km a day. 

I'll be doing this to raise money for High Peak Foodbank (Charity Number: 1159875) to support families in the High Peak during the COVID-19 pandemic and Syria Relief (Charity Number: 1143797) to support families who have left their homes due to the ongoing Syrian civil war and are now living in tents inside Syria and in the neighbouring countries of Lebanon, Iraq and Jordan.

Every penny donated will be split 50:50 between the two charities. JustGiving doesn't allow the function to be split at donation level, so it will initially go to Syria Relief who will then donate 50% of everything raisedd to High Peak Foodbank.

170 miles is the distance between Aleppo, Syria and Arsal, Lebanon - countless families have had to make this journey by foot, crossing the Anti-Lebanon Mountain range, to reach safety. Many who tried this journey froze to death. Suzanne and her children are just one family who made this journey, who Syria Relief support. https://www.facebook.com/syriareliefcharity/posts/2947371592044534
Title: Syria to Lebanon in High Peak

1 in 5 of the UK population lives below the poverty line.
