Description:
In these horrible times we are in and have ahead of us, I love hearing about all the charity work people are doing and I feel like I want to do my bit for something that I think is getting overlooked in these times. Admittedly i'm not going to be running a marathon or swimming the channel or even walking a 100 laps around my flat I just want to do something silly and raise a little bit of money for someone, all i'm going to be doing is dying my hair my fiances favourite colour of purple. If this dying malarkey fails (because shes doing it lol) i will be having to say good bye to my hair period that i've been trying to grow back for nearly a year now!!!!!!!! i know and understand my target isn't to the colonels level but every little helps but for every extra £50 i am agreeing to keep my hair purple/shaved for every month after lockdown aswell. so for example if i raise £100 i have to keep my hair purple/shaved until we have been out of lockdown for a month, £150 would be 2 months so on and so forth.  

More and more people are being forced to use food banks because they cannot afford the basics in life. Last year, food banks in the Trussell Trusts network provided 1.6 million three-day emergency food parcels to people in crisis, with over 500,000 of these going to children. This was an increase of almost 20% on the previous year.Now, as the Coronavirus pandemic develops, its likely that increasing numbers of people will need support from their local food bank. As food bank staff and volunteers work to source and distribute food to people who need support, their resources are becoming increasingly stretched as they come under additional pressure.Were working closely with our network of over 1,200 food banks to work out how we can best support each food bank in the coming months to make sure that theyre able to continue to help people in crisis in their local communities.

You can do so anonymously or with your name and a good luck message.

My aim for the BIG DAY is to identify 100 different species of birds on my patch - that is, on foot from my home in Wivenhoe, on 27th April.

I'll follow up this event with a bird finding series. You pay me an amount to find you a bird you've always wanted to see and enjoy. Really elusive or exotic birds will require a premium!

I'll reserve the 28th as a back-up day in case the weather is foul on 27th.

Thanks for reading this far and for considering helping Colchester Food Bank. If you want the money to be specifically reserved for Wivenhoe, say so on your message, but Colchester supports us with its warehousing and management, so it all helps!

Glyn’s Wivenhoe Bird Race
At precisely 4.30am I was aware of light filtering through the bedroom curtains...
Aaaagh – I’d missed my alarm! Fortunately, my accomplice for the day, Nick Green, had not and was making tea for a quick vigil on the back patio before we set out on the long tramp around Wivenhoe.
Although I had done some scouting for key breeding birds on territory, the cold, windy conditions would make it something of a lottery on the day – especially at dawn – as to whether the birds would betray their presence with any song.
The Tawny Owls we might have hoped to hear from the back patio drew a blank. The wind was such that we could not hear anything from the estuary as we sometimes can, so we set off at 04.55 for Ferry Marsh. High tide, for what it was worth (it wasn’t going to be e big one) was at around 07.30, so we simply walked around ferry marsh on the sea wall (it is still impassable due to flooding) without lingering. We picked up Sedge, Reed and Cettis warbler without any effort, plus Common & Lesser Whitethroat in the dawn chorus. No Chiffchaffs were heard until we walked back through the woods after looping through them from Lower Lodge after the return journey from opposite the Hythe on the trail. Along the river, we predictably scored Greenshank, Nightingale (2 territorial males either side of the river at Hythe), Common Tern and the more common waders, but no Spotted Redshank or Ruff as we might have hoped. A male Sparrowhawk swooped past us near the Uni and Bullfinches were barely audible above the breeze at the level crossing. The otherwise time-saving scope from Lower Lodge to the lagoons was passed up, but at great distance it would have been nigh impossible to see the Green Sandpipers and other smaller waders from that distance. We had seen 3 Avocets on the estuary the previous day, so felt confident that we would connect more easily than a long-range scan. With just over 2 hours to walk to the Hythe and then Wivenhoe Woods en route to Alresford Creek for high tide, we moved quite quickly. No Nightingales were in song in Wivenhoe wood. In fact, very few birds were evident. There were a couple of Jays to keep the total ticking over but by now, the lack of bird song was slightly concerning. A Cuckoo did at least make itself heard from across the river.
Back on the trail after Wivenhoe Woods, we connected with House Martins around West Quay. The walk to the creek yielded only Whimbrel and Bar-tailed Godwit, so we arrived at the metal bench with 40 minutes to scan across to Geedon Marsh before our breakfast rendezvous with Mark Norrington. A brief stop at the barrier did not yield Grey Wagtail, as hoped.
The vigil and the walk along to the bottom of Ford Lane for bacon rolls and coffee, courtesy of Mark, moved the species total from 62 to 71. We darted back to the creek mouth watch point as the wader and wildfowl count to that point was paltry... It seemed evident that most, if not all the usual wintering wildfowl and waders had cleared out, such that, other than the plentiful Whimbrels, we did not add anywhere near the numbers at Alresford that we had hoped, with Golden, Grey and Ringed Plover, Knot, Avocet, Spotted Redshank and Common Sandpiper all absent, as well as Wigeon, Teal and Brent Goose – all of which we would have expected.
We felt that we were 15 species short of where we needed to be when we dragged ourselves away from the creek with 79 species to our name, with one Mediterranean Gull making itself heard above the breeze. At least Little Owl provided an easy hit at Plumptons farm; Buzzards and Marsh Harriers were showing regularly without any thermals to speak of, but there were no more exotic raptors or larger migrants to add. We would have another chance with a later (not very) high tide late in the day, but at this stage, a total of 100 looked very distant, if not impossible without a significant fall of passage migrants. The walk along Cutthroat Lane to Sunnymead & Cockaynes was very quiet. Our remaining hopes of Treecreeper and Coal Tit would be at Cockaynes or Villa wood.
To our abject dismay, there was no Willow Warbler or Garden Warbler in song at Cockaynes. As the clock neared 1pm, I called Debbie to suggest she stays at home rather than deliver our lunch. Discretion became the better part and we managed to trek across Ballast Quay track to aarive back at home for an extended lunch break and a discussion on how we were even going to get over 90, let alone 100.
The biggest gaps in the list of hopefuls (if no longer probables) were of estuarine species, notable by their absence in the first tidal phase. Other incidental passerine species and their likely sites were well spread across the area. The other issue was that Nick had only just recovered from illness and we had already walked 12 miles on just a few hours sleep...
By the time we had eaten as many turkey sandwiches as we could, Nick had retired for a “lie down”. I thought that this would be effectively the end of his participation so togged up again and decided to head out to the creek, via the trail, to see if I could mop up some migrants and to get much luckier with estuarine species. Realistically, this was highly unlikely, but in the context of achieving the highest possible total, this was the obvious option.
To my amazement, as I neared the jetty, Nick called to say that he had woken after barely 30 minutes! We agreed to meet at the creek. By then, I had caught up with the pair of Grey Wagtails on the barrier having heard the male gently singing there from the jetty. The two birds showed briefly before I marched determinedly toward Nick.
Whilst there was nothing new on Barrier Marsh, I was tempted to stop briefly for a Nightingale that was very close to the path in an elevated position. I managed to zoom through a small opening to pick out the bird with the camera and stole quite a pleasing shot.
By the time I reached Nick at the bench, all threats of rain had gone and we enjoyed the next 90 minutes in mostly bright sunshine, doing our best to identify silhouetted images between us and Geedon saltings.
In this time, Nick did brilliantly to pick out a lone Brent Goose and I was able to lock on to a Great White Egret over the saltings. This put us on 82 for the day, but it was now obvious that the estuarine species had all but moved on. A flock of Dunlins were still in the creek, some of which were in almost full summer plumage, as were the Turnstones and 2 of the half dozen or so Bar-tailed Godwits to raise the spirits a little.
Had we stayed out for the rest of the day until dark, we might have added 2 or 3 more species, but there was no way we were going to get near 100, so we called it a day and declared our innings total at 82 species with 17 miles walked.
At the time of writing, we have raised £320 plus GiftAid. I will be doing other activities in a bid to raise this, including a bird finding schedule and making greeting cards with wildlife photos to benefit the Food Bank.

Description:
63 Air Assault Support Squadron RLC will be commemorating the 75th anniversary of VE Day by collectively completing a 75-hour triathlon.

75 soldiers and officers from the squadron will volunteer for one-hour slots to have all three disciplines in motion over 75 hours. There are 225 slots in total! The challenge will begin at 08:00hrs on Tuesday 5th May and conclude at 11:00hrs on Friday 8th May - just in time for the two-minute silence that the Nation will be observing to commemorate VE Day 75.

Why are we doing this? Due to the current pandemic, the nation has had very little cause for celebration recently. We want to do our upmost to commemorate this momentous day in history which saw WW2 come to an end in Europe.

In true British spirit we will also be rallying together to support two great charities: Colchester Foodbank and the Airborne Museum at Hartenstein.   

Colchester Foodbank supports people in poverty and in crisis. They provide nutritionally balanced emergency food and welfare support to local people who are referred to them. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. The foodbank is run by local people for local people, and they rely on the community’s support to provide much-needed help to people in crisis.  Our contributions will help them maintain essential stocks of key products, as well as running sustainable local projects.

The Airborne Museum at Hartenstein in Oosterbeek, Netherlands, commemorates the most famous parachute operation in the history of Airborne Forces – the Battle of Arnhem. The museum not only tells the story of the battle, but it is also a centre for international remembrance. They have come into financial difficulty after their grand-reopening was cancelled by the COVID-19 lockdown. The museum is dependent on funding from visitors and their continued operation has been jeopardised by the global pandemic. 

Any sharing, support, or donations, however small, will be hugely appreciated by all of us at 63 Squadron and our chosen charities.

No more than 3 people at any one time will be exercising and all will be compliant with the Government’s guidance on social distancing. Please stay at home, save lives, and protect the NHS!

Thank you for supporting our challenge!
Title: VE Day 75 Triathlon

Every year, Transmit organises a donation to Gateshead Foodbank to help put together their Christmas Hampers, and make a real difference to someone's Christmas. We have distributed donation boxes across the business centres in Gateshead Baltic Quarter and asked residents to donate a few items requested by the foodbanks. We understand not everyone can get to the business centres, but would still like to donate. 

Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, the Trussell Trust’s food bank network distributed 1,600,000 three-day emergency food supplies to those in crisis. More than half a million of these went to children.  
88,708 of these emergency food parcels were supplied in the North East of England. 

As Christmas draws close, it is important we help those who need it and spread a little joy. All donations are really appreciated and gratefully received.

Title: Transmit's Christmas Hamper Appeal

Description:
We are passionate St.Mirren supporters who run the Black & White Army supporters website and twitter page (@bawarmy).

On Dec 2nd we launched what we thought would be a bit of community minded festive fun ahead of a huge run of pre-Christmas fixtures for our team.

With Christmas on the way we are even more mindful of those in our local community who are struggling and following up on the amazingly successful Foodbank collections we've seen at the stadium in recent times we thought we'd join in and try and raise some funds for the Renfrewshire Foodbank.

Our challenge to the team was simple. For every point gained in the four fixtures leading up to Christmas the B&W Army site would donate £25 to the foodbank.That meant a glorious 12 point haul against Motherwell, Hamilton, Livingston and St.Johnstone would lead to a whopping £300 donation.

So then we started getting messages from other fans who wanted to join in, and it started to grow and grow and grow and we had pledges coming in from all over the place. That list of heroes who pledged is shown on our own site here at this link;

https://www.blackandwhitearmy.com/12pointsofchristmas

An incredible £2648 per point, pledged by almost 500 supporters!!!

The plan was, and still is, to tally up our points haul after the four matches and to contact all our pledgers on 22nd December to ask for their final donation.

We have however decided to open up the page now for a number of reasons;

1) Some supporters just want to make a one-off contribution
2) Plenty fans want to donate regardless of the results.We can't lie. There is always a risk that we lose all the games :-(
3) Fans can donate as they go, rather than all in one lump at the end
4) We appreciate the Foodbank may be especially stretched at this time of year.
5) We completely appreciate that everyones finances get hammered at this time of year!

So here we are, the page is open. We obviously don't know what our target is going to be as it will be dependent on the points we gain, but we're starting off with a 1 point target of £2648.

We will adjust and update the page as the matches are played.

Thanks to each and every person who has pledged and who has supported and shared this. Other football fans have also joined in which has been massively appreciated, and some of them aren't even from Renfrewshire which is even more amazing!
Title: B&W Army #12PointsOfChristmas

Description:
There are currently about 13 million people living below the food line in the UK alone. Colchester Food Bank are a local charity that are one of many charities in the UK trying to stop hunger nationwide.



Starting Monday 23RD NOV; Some of the Trampolining team are going to live below the poverty line for 5 days in order to raise awareness for Food poverty in the UK! We will be living of £1 food and drinks each day for 5 days! This means no luxuries just basic!


Along with other teams we will be posting videos and pictures of our daily meals and showing you how hungry we will be!



Our target is low but every little helps! we would love to more so please donate as much as you can and share with your friends and family!



You can also help by simply donating food to local food banks! it doesnt have to be money !! 



Keep updated using our hashtag #giveitfood2015 where we will be making short videos and taking pictures throughout the week of what food we buy, and how hungry we are etc.



Please donate as much or as little as you can to support Colchester Food Bank in the amazing work that they already do!!

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The Wellbeing Team at Sutton Uplift are taking on the 'live below the line challenge' - this will entail living on £1 a day, for five days, for all our food and drink. We are hoping to raise a minimum of £500 for Sutton's local foodbank and raise awareness locally by providing a small insight into the hardships faced by those experiencing extreme poverty.﻿﻿﻿

As a team we regularly bond together over food, often times, quite extravagantly. Our team meetings are subsidized with fruit and coffee and we spend a lot of our time together over food, lunch or snacks.To take on this challenge is going to be a difficult one for us.

Look out on our social media across the week of the challenge, from May 8th -  12th to see updates on how we are coping, recipes and meal plans and also local or national information on poverty reduction schemes and poverty-reduction initiatives.

Description:
During this pandemic we have seen communities come together
and people volunteering to help those in need.  The staff of Angus Council have been amazing throughout this period and we are all extremely proud of the work we do for and with our Council.  In times like this is it important to think of others and to give ourselves a different focus from the difficult times we are living in.  This virtual challenge has been set to give staff a reason to go out each day and get some exercise and to support the local foodbanks.

Our staff will be walking, cycling, running, rowing around the perimeter of Angus – 875 miles during the month of June.  Each day we will record the miles and hopefully by the end of the month we will have
virtually walked all around Angus’s beautiful towns and boundary.  

Our Angus Council staff and taking part and donating. Any further donations will encourage our staff to keep raising our total for the Angus Foodbanks.

Thank you for taking the time to read our story and why we have taken on this challenge at this time. 

Stay safe, stay healthy and protect or citizens.
Title: Angus Council Virtual Challenge

Description:
On the night of 25th January members of 40th Greenwich Scout Troop will be sleeping outside overnight in cardboard boxes to raise money for the Greenwich Foodbank.  The Met Office is forecasting temperatures to reach -1 C and last year the Scouts woke up to find their cardboard boxes covered in snow. 

We are packing our thermals, wooly hats and gloves. Hopefully we will get some sleep...

The Greenwich Foodbank provide nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to them in crisis. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. G40 are proud to support this local charity.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

This term all the children in year 5 took part in the Newcastle Building Society Boardroom Challenge which required us to come up with an idea for an event in support of a local charity. As a team we all decided we'd love to break a world record to support our school charity, The Gateshead Foodbank. We looked through the World Records database and found that the record for the World's Longest Food Passing Relay was yet to be broken. We thought that attempting this record would be a great way to raise awareness of and funding for the Foodbank.

To break the world record for the World’s Longest Food Passing
Relay we will need a minimum of 1000 people and 10 items of food. To achieve the record everyone must stand in a long line (like a very long snake!) and the first person in the line must pass each food item to the next person in line, and so on until all 1000 people have held each item of food. If we can achieve this we will have broken a world record!

Anyone is welcome to take part in our record attempt. However, even if you don't wish to take part you can still donate money to our cause. Wish us luck!

Description:
Please join me on the Boxing Day 2019 from Midday for my charity stream to help raise as much money as we can for such an amazing cause.

You can find me at www.twitch.tv/nelinde

If you can't make a donation fear not! You can help by spreading the word and sharing this JustGiving page on social media and with friends and family.


No one should go hungry, especially at Xmas! 

Yet thousands of families are going without food due to poverty, parents going without so their children don't have empty bellies.

This is 2019! This shouldn't even be a thing... Sadly so many people in the UK are in this dire situation. It could be a neighbour or even a family member!

UK Food Banks are vastly overstretched and are in need of food donations more than ever before to meet the highest demands ever to be recorded since the Trussell Trust started in 1999!


But you can help spread a little Xmas cheer <3 


Please spare what you can afford, as little as £2 can afford a single meal!

You can also help by donating any spare "long shelf life" foods such as tinned vegetables etc to your local Food Bank or supermarket Food Bank collection box <3

Having personally relied on my local Food Bank in previous times of hardship I have first hand experience of the effect and contribution Food Banks have on so many people facing financial hardship and not being able to afford food for their families or themselves. They provide a light in times of darkness, often providing much more than just food. 

They offer an ear to listen, a personal connection where there is nothing but loneliness. Many Food Banks even provide clothing that they've had donated. My local Food Bank even run a free playgroup where parents can go to meet other parents and make friendships.

I can't stress how much a small donation can help <3

Description:
Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group’s £2 Challenge! 

We've been thinking of a way for our Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group to help people at this difficult time, without asking too much when most of us are anxious about money and the future.

Having kept in touch with the Bridgend Foodbank Charity, we think it will be really helpful to raise money for their volunteer-run base here. They make sure people across Bridgend have emergency food and basics, and rely heavily on donations which are more difficult to safely collect and accept at the moment. 

Our wonderful, supportive and positive group now has 8,000 members from across Bridgend including people who live here, work here and have loved ones here. And we thought, what if each of us donated just £2 to Bridgend Foodbank? Collectively we could raise a lot of money for them and make a huge difference to people in our community. 

Please get involved if you can :)

The Just Giving page is linked to the Bridgend Foodbank Donation page and all funds will go directly to them.
Title: Bridgend Coronavirus Support Group's 2pound Challenge

Description:
Alreet!

So, as an amatuer cyclist (very amatuer) I've decided to channel some spare pandemic time into a postive cause. Myself and my girlfriend have been training for a 100km cycle around London, visiting 10 football stadiums, plus Wembley.

The route we've planned for Thursday *11 June is:

Arsenal > Tottenham > Leyton Orient > West Ham > Millwall > Crystal Palace > Chelsea > Fulham > QPR > Brentford > Wembley

The cause we have chosen is Newcastle West End Foodbank. The demand for food banks has , sadly, never been greater. Ordinarily this charity supplements it's food and cash donations with a stand outside St. James' Park on Newcastle match days. The pandemic has taken away this vital supply line (a bi-weekly footfall loss of 50,000+). 

So I wanted to try and raise the amount an average season ticket at Newcastle costs.

Follow our efforts on my Twitter (@Ketchell) Instagram (@Ketchfootball) and via the hashtag #TourDeStadeLDN

*UPDATE*

Awful weather on 11 June has meant we have been forced to postpone until the end of the month! We've relocated to the North East for a two-week training camp in the meantime!
Title: The #TourDeStadeLDN

This year is a bit different as we won’t be able to hold our annual office food collection.  However we can still play our part in Making Changes Together.  This page will be available between Monday 29th June - Friday 31st July 2030. The donations will help Renfrewshire Food bank buy the food items that they are low on and to plan for the weeks and months ahead in what is a very busy time for them.    

Last years collection raised 433.95kg which was 1,033 meals for the people of Renfrewshire.  Together we can all help boost last years collection.  All donations received will be to purchase food which will be weighed and outlined in how many meals it will provide.

Description:
Last year Gateshead College’s mental health champions launched the Ultimate Walk & Talk, a 20-mile or 8-mile challenge walking to each of the college’s campuses. It was a huge success with more than 50 members of staff taking part and completing an incredible 1,632,500 steps.

Due to the success of last year’s walks, the Ultimate Walk & Talk is returning in 2020 but, because of Covid-19, we are now making it virtual.

Our new challenge is to walk the same distance during Mental Health Awareness Week between Monday 18th May and Friday 22nd May. Everyone taking part will sign-up to either an 8 or 20-mile challenge. This year’s theme is kindness and we are going to be walking to feed families in need, with donations going to Gateshead Foodbank.

This money will be used by the Foodbank to feed local people in crisis – so that no one in our community has to go hungry.

Description:
There are currently about 13 million people living below the food line in the UK alone. Colchester Food Bank are a local charity that are one of many charities in the UK trying to stop hunger nationwide. 

So, 16 of our lovely girls from the Essex Blades Netball Club are taking part in the 'Living Below The Line' challenge (alongside other people from the uni). This is where we live off of £1 a day, for 5 consecutive days! This includes all food and drink for the week (even alcohol), so there will be no such thing as luxuries during this week! During these 5 days we will all be carrying out our normal daily routines, but most importantly we will be collecting food, and raising money for the life changing charity that is Colchester Food Bank. We will all be doing this very very HUNGRY!!

Keep updated using our hashtag #giveitfood2015 where we will be making short videos and taking pictures throughout the week of what food we buy, and how hungry we are etc.

Please donate as much or as little as you can to support Colchester Food Bank in the amazing work that they already do!!

Description:
A group of 15 soldiers from 3Rifles will be embarking on a charity to Cycle, Tab, run and walk the distance of 3700.5 miles in 2months, starting 06/05/20 ending 06/07/20. 

The miles is from Edinburgh to Italy, Spain, France, London and back up to Edinburgh. These are the worse affected European countries for COVID-19. 

Each member will aim to do about 246.07 miles in 2months, roughly about 4.11 miles per day. All money raised will go towards food banks. This is to cater for emergency supplies to help the thousands of people who have lost their jobs, and in dire need for basic food, and other necessities. Lets not forget the homeless, as we know that some of our veterans are also homeless and they depend heavily on food banks. 

To that end the team is humbly appealing for any amount of donation that you could contribute to go toward families and homeless people badly affected by COVID-19.

The challenge: Virtually walk the total ditance of the length of the 3 rivers that flow to the sea in Cardiff; Taff, Ely, Rhymni.

When:  betweeen the 18th and 22nd May 2020.

Instructions: Follow Welsh Government guidlines on distancing. Walking with other members of the household is allowed. Take photographs to post on the Ysgol Glantaf Twitter account (@Ysgol_Glantaf).

Description:
Hello. Like many people I've been running to try and stay sane during the lockdown. My mileage has crept up to approaching a half marathon, so  I thought I'd push through to 13.1 miles and use it as an opportunity to try and raise some money for good causes. 

Primarily I'm raising money for the local food bank so they can help people struggling during the incoming recession. I'll also donate an additional 50% of whatever I raise to Music Venues Trust, who are trying to stop grassroots music venues from closing. Across the UK, 35% of venues have closed after the last decade. With venues forced to close during the lockdown, and possibly some of the last businesses to re-open, there's a real risk that many more will close without our support in the coming months. Thanks!

As I'll be running on my own, I will only be competing against myself when I ran a half marathon a decade ago. If I don't beat Young Robin on the first go I will keep going until I do. In the interests of transparency, my previous time was 1 hour 44 minutes, which is incidentally faster than TV's Andrew Lincoln who ran the Cardiff Half the same year.

Title: Fir Vale School Amsterdam Cycle Challenge!

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Food banks in the UK provide an invaluable service to those who, for a multitude of reasons, are unable to afford the basic food they need.

In 2008/09 the Trussell Trust, of which Greenwich Foodbank is a part, gave out around 25,000 food parcels over the course of the year. In 2018/19 they gave out over 1,500,000. That is a 5,900% increase in need in the fifth largest economy in the world.

On the longest day of 2020, 20th June my brother and I (and potentially a special guest) will be undertaking the longest single ride we have ever done. We will be riding, non-stop for 24 hours to raise much-needed funds and awareness for the fantastic work this group does. I live close to where Greenwich Food Bank is based and so it is a charity that means a lot to me.

We will be starting from the northern tip of London, and will be riding north to...wherever we can reach in 24 hours!

This will be a supported effort and we will have a car following us to bring us food and water to enable us to focus on distance rather than finding places to stop and refuel.

We will be updating the page as we plan the route and the feeding plan to give us the best chance of success.

The initial target will be 400 KM which will mean averaging around 17kph every hour for all 24 hours.
Title: Lucas's 24 Hours on 2 wheels

Description:
Tomorrow should have been the 11th Jam in the Castle but sadly we have had to postpone due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To say we’re disappointed is an understatement. We love hosting the event which has raised tens of thousands over the last 10 years.

But just because COVID-19 has postponed the show it doesn’t mean we still can’t enjoy the spirit of Jam.

This year we’re supporting Bridgend Food Bank. Even though we can’t all meet up in the Castle we can still have our own Jam in our Gardens and still raise money for an amazing cause.

So take a look at our page, replay the videos, look at the photos and relive Jams 1-10!

Why not send us photos or videos of your Jam in the Castle memories or if you’ve performed in the past send us a performance from home.

If you can donate a small amount to Bridgend Food Bank please do. We’ve got an army of amazing supporters who can still make a huge differed even though we can’t all be together tomorrow.

We’ll be back soon.

YOU CAN’T STOP THE JAM!
Title: Martin's Jam In The Castle - Bridgend Food Bank Appeal

Description:

I intend starting at 7pm on Wednesday 1st July and finish at 7.30 am . on the 2nd July . I will check in occasionally on Facebook during the pianathon .

Description:
Anyone who knows me well knows that I like presents. A lot. But what I like even more is food. I am fortunate enough to be able to eat food whenever I want. Lots of people can't and that makes me sad. So this year I'm donating my birthday to the Colchester Food Bank and I want you to make me happy by giving my present to this brilliant organisation and making Christmas just that little bit easier for people who are struggling.

Here's how it works:

For those of you who love me dearly - You need to donate one pound for every one of my glorious years. I'll do the maths for you, that's 33 pounds each. No sharing.

For those of you who like me but not enough to get me a present - fair enough. If you'd like to give even a few pounds as a token of your appreciation that would be awesome.

For those of you who are super organised and already got me a present - fear not. Christmas is just around the corner.

Description:
We are sleeping out in cardboard boxes overnight on the 25th January with our scout troop to raise funds for our local foodbank.  It is going to be very cold (-1deg) but we hope it will be dry and for once we are hoping that it does not snow!!

But we will not be hungry, unlike the increasing number of local people referred to the Greenwich Foodbank where they are provided with   nutritionally balanced emergency food and support.  Greenwich Foodbank is part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK. We are proud to support this local charity. 

We would very much appreciate if you could make a small donation to our chosen charity the Greenwich Foodbank.

Title: Emilys Cut for Covid

Description:
It's my first birthday on May 9th! I wish I could be spending it with my friends and family having a great big party, but because of this horrible virus I will be separated from my loved ones. I am a very lucky boy who has lots of lovely things and people keep asking my mummy and daddy what I would like for my birthday. What I'd really like is to be with those I love, but I can't. So what I'd really like is for everyone to have a garden party at their home and to donate any of the money that would be spent on travel, presents or food contributions to go to the Stockport Food bank. 

I'd also love people to send lots of pictures of themselves having loads of fun at my great big party, and now it doesn't matter how far away you are we can all have a big party together on May 9th. 

Stockport food Bank provides support and food parcels across Stockport, providing food to people in crisis.

Title: Milton Challenge July

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On Sunday 28’June 2020 I was supposed to be competing in the Round Sheffield Run (a c.15mile challenge) for the 3rd consecutive year. This year I’ve trained better than ever and despite the event being postponed (& rescheduled) for January 2021 I wanted to do something as a culmination of my training. As such instead of tackling the hills of Sheffield I’m running round Newark.

During the COVID crisis I’ve been blessed with good health and a bit of spare time which has enabled me to give up some time to help as a volunteer at the Food Bank. It is a sad reflection of our times that despite the apparent “wealth” of our country so many families are living in poverty. Therefore I’ve decided to raise money for a great local cause.

Description:
Over the next month Sophie is careering through TWO marathons in her buggy. That’s at least 52.438 miles.

Sophie would be THRILLED if you sponsor her as she is really worried about people going hungry, but isn’t big enough to do anything about it yet. If you donate, she might even give you a clap. 

Demand for the local volunteer-run Tottenham Foodbank has gone up 100% since March 2020 and they need £100k to cope.

A bit more info on the Foodbank:

Tottenham Foodbank helps individuals and families in crisis through the provision of emergency food supplies. The circumstances surrounding a crisis are unique to every individual, so we partner with frontline care professionals, such as health visitors, social workers and other community-based support workers, who are able to identify and refer people facing hunger to the foodbank. As well as receiving nutritionally-balanced 3 day food parcels, people are welcomed with a cup of tea, listened to and signposted to agencies that are able to help resolve the underlying cause of the problem.Our foodbank was created through a partnership between Freedoms Ark Church and Crutch Haringey, in conjunction with the Trussell Trust. 

The Trussell Trusts UK foodbank network will create a UK with no need for food banks.  last year it collected more than 10,000 tonnes of food and gave over 1,084,604 three days food supplies to people in crisis of which over 396,000 went to children.For more info and for other ways to donate, please visit https://www.justgiving.com/crowdfunding/tottenham-foodbank
Title: Sophie.s super stroller marathon

Description:
Ay up mi duk! We're the Calverton Plough Boys. 

We perform a traditional St George's mummers play on the nearest Saturday to St George's Day every year to raise funds for charity ...

... but this year the pubs are shut. 

Ah bum. 

So, instead, we've made a silly film to replace this year's live performance, spliced together from our various places of isolation. We'll be inflicting it on the World Wide Web on Saturday 25 April. We already feel very sorry for you.

Please watch and share the film to literally millions of your friends on social media. Be sure to also share our fundraising link, and donate a few quid to Arnold Food Bank, our chosen charity this year. 

Visit: www.calvertonploughplay.co.uk for more info, and to see the film when it's released!
Title: The Calverton St George's Play (Online) 2020

Description:

﻿﻿Over 90% of food bank stock comes from donations they receive from the general public.  During these unprecedented times the need for food parcels has increased but the donation rate has fell dramatically.  This means the amount of help which local charities can give to the most vulnerable in our local area has fell when it's needed most.

Gateshead food bank also provides essential non food items such as toiletries and female hygiene products. 

Gateshead food bank will provide a 3 day supply for either individuals or families that need their help.

They urgently need our help both during and after this pandemic.  Can you help?  If everyone donated the pennies for just a tin of beans, imagine the difference we can make!

Together as a staff we have been trying to help the community as much as we can in these hard times. A Rainbow Walk is something that we can all take part in as a school community while following the social distancing rules. We want to encourage as many people as possible to go out for a Rainbow Walk (run/cycle) on Thursday 28th May. Our target is to get out for our walk for half an hour. We can dress in rainbow colours, create rainbow flags to wave, spot rainbow pictures in windows and tie rainbow ribbons to the school railings if you would normally pass the building on your walk or your own fence/ gate/ tree so that we can see where our walkers have been on our fundraising day. 

Whilst doing this we need to make sure we are being safe and sticking to the current advice and rules. Everyone will complete their walk (run/cycle) with members of their own household at a time that suits them throughout the day. 

All the money raised will go to Kirkcaldy Foodbank. Many families in our community will be finding things difficult with job losses and lots of uncertainty. With many extra people accessing the Foodbank throughout the town, any money raised will be greatly appreciated. 

So please join in with us and have some fun. If you can donate we are grateful of any donation, however big or small. 

We are missing our 'normal' day to day and seeing all of the children, parents and carers too. Please stay safe and remember to take some pictures while you are out on your Rainbow Walk and send them to us via Twitter @kirkcaldywestps or your individual class on Microsoft Teams.

Thank you

KWPS Team
Title: Keep Walking Powering Supporting

Description:
UPDATE: We have now completed the challenge....I can confirm that we made it safely to Newfoundland in the given time but will give a fuller update at the end of the week with exactly how far...

Thank you to those of you who have donated so far- we are thrilled to have made our fundraising target in supporting Portsmouth Foodbank. For those of you who have not yet donated, there is, of course, still plenty of time to do so.

From 23rd May, 16 tutors and two Heads of Year will be taking on an epic journey. The Middle School team will be attempting to cover the distance from Portsmouth Grammar School to Newfoundland, Canada- some 3935 km.

Over the course of a month the team will be running, cycling, walking, rowing- anything that can be measured safely whilst respecting current rules on social distance and exercise- in order to raise money for Portsmouth Foodbank. 

The Middle School team has always worked together very closely: our Common Room space acts as an important hub for staff as well as pupils, and we run a variety of fun events such as discos, the annual ski trip, our Little Canada adventure and, of course a number of charity  fundraisers. With this ethos in mind, each member of the team plans to contribute to the challenge in whatever way they possibly can, covering distances big or small using their own preferred method.

If we manage to complete the distance before a month is up we will keep count of kms covered and see if there are any other interesting landmarks we can get to. If we don't manage it, we will keep going and see how much longer after the month it takes. 

Finally, the serious bit: the coronavirus pandemic has placed unprecedented strain on foodbank services throughout the UK as more and more people find themselves in difficult financial positions as a result of the changing economic landscape. If you are able to, please do consider donating to support those most in need in our community.

Description:
Thank you for supporting S6 Foodbank. Every donation made goes directly to support their work.

Without the assistance of people and businesses in Sheffield, S6 Foodbank wouldnt be able to continue to support their guests, launch new sites and tackle the ongoing food crisis in Sheffield which is being exacerbated by coronavirus.

S6 Foodbank are expecting the increased need to continue for the foreseeable future, as more people experience difficulty as a result of coronavirus and its wider consequences. I believe that nobody in Sheffield should have to face going hungry. 

A donation of £27 provides food and basic essentials for a family of three for three days. I am aiming to raise at least £40 to help S6 Foodbank reach their £40,000 target. Whatever I raise (up to that target) will be match-funded by the Government via the Love Your Neighbour partnership, meaning S6 Foodbank receives double the amount.

Thank you for sponsoring me, and a huge thank you too from Chris and the team
Title: ALEXANDRA's Stepping out for S6

Description:
My name is Freddie. I am 5 years old and I am cycling as much as I can to raise money for our local Foodbank in Earlsfield, London. 

My goal originally was to cycle 50 miles before school starts at the beginning of June but now I am trying to get to over 100! I am nearly there now. 

St Andrew's engages and support many charitable causes with the aim of helping those in need in Earlsfield and beyond. Responding to the Covid-19 crisis, they support a range of community initiatives including: - The Community Kitchen: Their usually vibrant Home Community Café at St Andrews Church is now the community's kitchen. Cooking hot meals for the vulnerable and needy. - Earlsfield Foodbank: The Foodbank is being run temporarily from St Andrews as well. Food is distributed from the church every Thursday, with home deliveries to the housebound. The Earlsfield Community Response Fund will help them help with the costs of such inspiring community initiatives and will be available for other groups who need funds.Everyone cared for; no one alone.
Title: Freddie's Frog cycling challenge

Description: My challenge is to run 10k a week, for 10 weeks, starting this week (8th June 2020) and raise some money for UK foodbanks.I enjoy running because it makes me feel energised and relaxed, and I get to race my Dad! If you see me running please cheer me on.

Description:
Like many many folk I have watched U.K. politics with sense of concern about what is happening. 

I’m one person. And I don’t feel equipped academically or politically to change things. But I want to try. So this is my first tiny step.

Title: Commercial's National Three Peaks Challenge page

Description:
Theresa May is rightly very concerned about the welfare of her 33 MPs who needlessly lost their job last Thursday due to an electorate who won't do as it is told.

She has pledged to use Tory funds to help in this time of crisis but once Rupert gets wind of his money being used to fund scroungers she will surely U-turn.

The maths is chilling. As we know a solid breakfast costs 8p. If we extrapolate that to 3 meals, allowing a generous double helping for dinner, that is 32p per day.

It could be as long as four months until the next general election so that is 119 days - almost as long as a benefit sanction - these 33 poor souls will need to scrape by on only 28 thousand pounds (20 thousand euros) loss of office payment.

They have taken so much from society, isn't it time we gave them something more?

Title: Richard's Step Up September 2019

Description:
The Salvation Army is a Christian Church & registered Charity working in 130 countries worldwide and is one of the largest and most diverse providers of social welfare in the world. In the UK and Republic of Ireland this work includes more than 800 Salvation Army social service centres and community churches. We provide unconditional friendship, support and very practical help to people in crisis and need and work with children, homeless people, all adult victims of modern slavery and those dealing with drug and/or alcohol addiction.

In Hythe, we've been active as a Church and serving the community for nearly 125 years, including through the provision of practical support in times of need. In recent days our foodbank has seen a spike in usage and individuals are finding it difficult to get out of the house to donate food. We've set up this page so that people can make a monetary donation which can be used to purchase food.

Title: Ian's 12 Hour Non Stop DJ Set

Description:
Hello, Treasures!

This year, I've decided to give myself a tough challenge to raise money for a cause that is very dear to my heart. I am going meat-free for a whole month for the Trussell Trust, which runs foodbanks up and down the country providing desperate people with the means to feed their families in times of financial crisis.

Doesn't seem like much of a challenge to some people. But those of you who know me well know that I love my meat. I eat meat almost every day. It is always the focus of my evening meal and forms a large part of my diet. Pork, chicken, beef, lamb, even venison... I love it all!

However, I've become increasingly aware of how much meat I eat and I've decided to see if I can go without it for a whole month. There are so many people in this country who cannot afford to buy fresh food for their families, which is why I want to use this opportunity to raise money for the Trussell Trust.  And I need YOUR help to keep me in check!

As long as you donate any amount of money for me to do this, I know I cannot cheat or let myself slide at any point. 

These are the conditions I have set myself for this challenge:

  • No meat or poultry
  • No fish or seafood
  • No meat substitutes, e.g. Quorn, imitation soy products such as soy mince

Just good old vegetables, pulses, carbohydrates and probably lots of cheese and eggs, too! 

This is going to be hard for me but it's for such a worthy cause. The UK's use of foodbanks has increased dramatically over the past couple of years due to the government's cuts in welfare for the poorest in our society. Children everywhere are struggling to eat and this is why foodbanks need the money to help families survive hard times. 

Between April and September 2015 alone, Trussell Trust foodbanks across the UK gave 506,369 three day emergency food supplies to people in crisis compared to 492,641 in the same period last year. 185,218 of the three day supplies went to children.

So please give whatever you can afford. By donating, you'll not only be helping me stick to my challenge, but you'll also be ensuring that more families can be fed through the Trussell Trust.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I'll be posting updates on my progress, including photos of my homemade veggie meals, on Facebook and Twitter, and perhaps a few video diary entries just for your entertainment.

Thanks for reading, and, echoing what we always chanted at the end of charity assemblies at school, please give generously!

Shiraz
Xxxxxx

Description:
A year ago, I was the Labour Party's General Election candidate for Dudley South. During my campaign I talked to hundreds of local families, many of whom shared with me how difficult it is to make ends meet. One young mum, on a bitterly cold day, told me she only had 80p left on her electricity meter and another spoke about how much harder it is in school holidays when her kids aren't getting fed at school. 

This was a year ago.

Since then, Coronavirus is pushing more families into poverty.

There are over 2,000 children in receipt of Free School Meals in Dudley South and many thousands more across the Black Country more widely. I would like to raise some funds to help the local food bank support them and their families this half-term and beyond.

Thank you for your support

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am looking to raise money for West Lothian Food Bank because we cannot leave the most vulnerable people in our community behind, especially at this time of year. 

We have seen all over the news the debate regarding Free School Meals for children, which are thankfully being supported in Scotland. But the issue is wider and deeper. Food bank usage has continued to increase  alarmingly and further support is needed to help this vital lifeline continue to support the people who need it. 

We have a responsibility to the vulnerable people in our community. We have a responsibility to help those who have so very little, even if we ourselves only have a little more. Where I was brought up - no one got left behind. People look out for one another. That's what I am asking for today. 

If you can donate, I would be ever so grateful. No matter how little, everything makes a difference. If you could spare the price of a pint or a coffee that would be magic. If you can't donate, then please share, share, share!

Lets go, WestLo!

TLD xo

Title: Parkwood Tinto trek page

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As I’ve been in lockdown with two little ones I’ve had more time than ever to reflect on our situation and what lockdown would be like for those less fortunate. I myself have been in that position many years ago and remember how hard it was to ask for help. With the recession  hitting the UK hard and more and more families out of jobs every day, there is going to be an greater need for food banks and good will of people more fortunate to help support those that aren’t. 

I’ve set up this page to raise as much money as possible for our local food bank especially as the need for food will increase as we approach the winter months and people will be forced to have to make the hard choice between spending money on food or heating. 

No baby, child, teenager, young person, adult, or elderly person should have to be making these choices. Our government should be doing more to help, but unfortunately that’s not happening. So we need to take matters into our own hands and help those that need it the most. 

Please give what ever you can, a little goes a long way if everyone can chip in ❤️

This year the Youth Pilgrimage has been cancelled due to the Covid-19 Pandemic. The lockdown and current restrictions also mean, that with the drop in hall lettings and plate collections, St Luke's is currently running at a significant loss.

To fundraise for St Luke's over the next 2 weeks, I intend to walk 123 miles around our parish, praying for it as I go - the same distance as it is between Woodside and Walsingham.

Description:

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, this year has been one of the hardest years for many people.
People losing their jobs, pay cuts, redundancy, businesses closing. These times would be hard for anyone, but especially those who have young families, and are finding it difficult to provide for themselves and their children. I don’t know about you, but as a young family myself who is able to support; there’s nothing worse than knowing of those who are not being able to provide for those we love and care for the most.

We here at PLS would like to help those most in need and make sure those families are able to go to places like the Black Country Food Bank, and make sure they have food on the table.

Title: Amii's Black Country Food Bank

Description:
In this run up to Christmas, it should remain at the forefront of our minds the amazing and unfortunately necessary work that Stoke-on-Trent Food Bank do for the community.

2020 has been one hell of a year, and the Covid-19 crisis has only done more to exasperate the need within our communities for this vital
service. It is cold and bleak out there, and countless people are reliant on food banks to prevent hunger. 

Last year’s appeal was wonderful. We broke all expectations, and we have never been prouder of what our small community was able to achieve. Every little donation helps in this campaign, and we recognise that everyone is feeling some difficulty right now. We aren’t out to smash last year’s sum (£1,342 after setting an initial target of £200!), as wonderful as that would be.

We just want to support our community, and do our part, and (as some more talented people have said) leave the world a little bit better than we found it.

Description:
Share a Cuppa Comfort with someone in need of a food parcel this Winter.

The idea behind the #shareacuppa campaign is to do what we do best when times are tough and reach out with a big mug of metaphorical love for someone who really needs a cuppa.

For the price of a cuppa tea you could help ensure someone is fed this Winter.

5 Cuppas = 1 3 day food parcel for a family of 4

Food poverty is a critical issue here in Birmingham, and numbers are soaring of those in need. At Aston & Nechells Foodbank we are providing near double our YoY food parcel numbers and this is only going to increase as the Covid Crisis extends.

If you can share the price of a cuppa tea to help a hungry person today. Please do.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My kids love Halloween trick or treating around Riverside View and it gets better every year! This year is different in so many ways but the kids have had enough taken from them. Lets keep the joy alive by decorating our houses as normal and also displaying a poster. Rather than trick or treating and giving out sweets, children can try and spot as many posters in windows/porches etc as possible. Our families remain safe and the children have a spooky trail to follow. How many posters will they spot? Plus, we can donate the money we would spend on sweets and treats to help those that have suffered during this difficult time. Win-win!

I have created the poster in black and white so that it can be coloured in by your little pumpkins (or yourself)! You can find the poster posted on the Riverside View residents only facebook group or left-click on the cover picture at the top of this page and save the image so you can print it out.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page 

Last year I decided to support my Muslims students by committing to do half of Ramadan with them. The experience gave me an insight into the difficulties faced by many who have access to little food on a day-to-day basis. This insight has motivated me to try to complete the full 30 days this year to support both my students and charities who work to ease the impact of food poverty in the local area. I will be collecting donations for the foodbank whilst I complete my fast so please have a dig in your cupboards for tinned/packeted food, go out and spend a pound on some food or send some money my way to purchase some food on your behalf. I will happily come and collect donations so please let me know if you have anything to give. I've already had £20 off some lovely people to set the ball rolling ❤️

38% of households in Stoke-on-Trent are living on less than £16,000 per year (the minimum amount required to access basic goods and services in Britain. Hardship Commission – Stoke-on-Trent, 2015).

Description:
Dear friends and colleagues, 

Welcome to our third annual winter fundraiser! Last year we raised £500 for Jimmy's homeless shelter, so we hope we can top that! This year we are raising funds for the Cambridge City Foodbank again. Winter can be very difficult for those in our communities who are struggling, and the holidays can exacerbate that. The Foodbank is seeded by the Trussell Trust and provides food, sanitary and household supplies, and meter cards for gas and electricity to people in need. 

Food bank use is at an all-time high in the UK and your donations of food and money will go a long way. This winter, help people who are forced to decide to 'heat or eat', and bring some holiday comfort to people in need! Here's how you can help:

1. Donate food. If you are based in the Department of Archaeology, please take part in our food drive. There is a box in the coffee room for supplies and updated shopping lists alongside it.

2. Donate money using this page.

You can get more info about the Cambridge City Food Bank here: https://cambridgecity.foodbank.org.uk/

Thank you for your donations!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Title: Winter Fundraiser for Cambridge City Food Bank

Description:
The challenge: To notice one small thing/detail in my environment each day this month and to share it on the Facebook page, as either a photo, tiny piece of art or haiku. Some of these may be wonderful, some may be terrible. The idea is to do it and share it regardless!


Why: Over the last 2 years or so, illness and disability have left me almost housebound and needing a lot of time in bed.
I've decided I need to set myself one tiny, manageable creative goal each day to stop life just passing by in a blur.

At the same time I still want to find ways to contribute to my community and to things that mean a lot to me.
Combining my little daily goal with a fundraiser seemed one way I could do that.

If you'd like to follow along, whether you donate or not, please come and visit the Noticing September Facebook page 

https://www.facebook.com/Noticing-September-108538293858525/

Thanks xx

Title: Scottish's Scotfreelancers Christmas Fundraising

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We as a local community studio based in Brockley, London SE4 wanted to support a local charity during this time and so our team of experienced yoga and pilates teachers will be holding a Yogathon for Lewisham food bank on the 2nd May 2020.

The food banks provide food parcels to be delivered to those in need. People that live in poverty as well as the vulnerable that are isolated. 

During the event our team of teachers will be holding an event in which all the experienced participating teachers will teach a segment of a longer class. It will be a way of connecting our community that since going fully virtual has expanded to people all around the world. It will also be an opportunity to experience all our amazing teachers in a single afternoon during what could be a really crazy random class. 

If you wish to be involved you can either sign up for the event and donate directly or even get sponsored for your participation. If you are not able to participate but would like to donate directly please do. It will not be easy as it will be about 2 hours long but will be a lot of fun!!!. You can rest as much as you need so don’t be too scared of joining in and looking after yourself during the event.

Please support us, to support the food banks as during this time the poverty and hardships that people are experiencing are even more prominent than usual.
Title: Renaissance Yogathon

Description:
The Lewisham foodbank is run by local people for local people – they rely on the community’s support to ensure they can continue to stop people going hungry. 

50% of my revenue from online teaching during the Covid-19 crisis will go to Lewisham Food Bank to provide emergency food supplies to people who need it most.

4327 three-day emergency food supplies were given to people in crisis last year. An emergency pack contains three-days’ nutritionally balanced, non-perishable tinned and dried foods

During this time especially, there are many people in need of emergency food supplies. Please donate whatever you can (even £1 helps) or to your local food bank. 

Find your local food bank: https://www.trusselltrust.org/get-help/find-a-foodbank/

Title: Daniel's Purchase4Poverty

Description:
As somebody who was lucky enough to be born round about this
time of year, December’s always been a month of receiving for me. This year I’d like to change that, and instead of receiving presents I’d like to give something back to a community that is now in need of help more than ever.

Having had a rather hedonistic time at uni (still embarrassed
about that time I ate a whole pasta bake for four in one sitting tbh), and in light of the political events of last week, I’ve been doing a lot of reflecting on my own relative privilege and the state of the world around me. You can’t really turn on the news, or go on social media without being reminded that the world is a Horrible Place, and there’s very little you can do about it. Bad people are in charge, everything is getting hotter, and I’m never going to reach 5’4”. It’s all very disheartening.

So if other people can’t make good things happen, I’m going
to try my very best to do it myself. During the pre-election madness, I saw numerous statistics on Twitter that really shocked me, and in particular quite a few on food bank usage in the UK. More people are using food banks than ever before, and this number has increased from the tens of thousands in 2010 to the millions this year. The reasons behind this increase can be disputed to no end, but I think regardless of political persuasion you can agree that they’re a
highly valuable resource for many. One that shouldn’t need to exist, but one that pretty much means life or death for those that need them.

For that reason I’d like to collect donations for the North
Bristol Foodbank this year, the foodbank that’s local to both myself and many of you that I know. There’s been a 54% increase in demand from North Bristol foodbank from April-Sept 2019, and as the winter draws in, the demand only increases. Christmas isn’t going to be the best time of year for many, and even if you can’t donate I hope you can keep them on your mind over the festive season.

I’ve created this page for any donations you’d like
to make! I would appreciate them much more than any Christmas/birthday presents (although if you’ve already bought them, I won’t say no…), and they’ll do much more good as well. Also, if you’re around to give me something in person, you have no excuse now 😊

Thanks!
Title: Mee-Mee's Birthday

Description:
Badreddin Salhani-Maat (17-11-1947 to 31-03-2020)


Bob was born in Syria and later reluctantly came to the UK to support his father to become a gynaecologist.  After a few years he decided to stay on in the UK while his family returned back to Syria.  He fell into a career as a maths teacher.   Despite his deteriorating vision he carried into his 50s. He was a kind hearted and generous man who touched many lives.  Nothing was impossible. He raised three independent children who will be forever grateful for all he did for them.  He acquired a few extra children who saw as equals to his own children.  He has four beautiful grand children who adore him.  He will be truly missed. 


Instead of flowers and cards, he would have preferred donations to those in need. He always enjoyed feeding the troops.

Title: intY Fitness Challenge

Description:
We are Ezra (8) and Remy (6) and we love to draw! We would like to combine our love of drawing with raising money for our local foodbank during these difficult times when people need it the most. We would like to create portraits of people's pets for them to keep, and to make them smile. We will send them as a digital copy and then give paper copies to people if they want them after the lockdown has ended. 

Please email a photo of your pet to our mum Rachael at: raqu520@aol.com along with your pet's name and we will send our portrait back to you! 

The Morecambe Bay Foodbank exists to help people in crisis by providing three days' worth of emergency food. We also provide school uniforms to children who need them in the area through our Uniform Project. Can you help us to raise funds to pay for a new van so that we can continue our work? Our old van is getting too small and we need a new one so that we can keep on working to feed and help people in the area.

Thank you so much for looking at our page and remember to send us your pet photos to Rachael Gibson at: raqu520@aol.com.

Title: 90 books before I'm 9

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

 These are very uncertain trying times, and I know there are plenty of people out there who currently rely on the fantastic service their local food banks have to offer. Why am I doing this? Well, I've seen similar things happening elsewhere and whilst trying to find ways to help out locally I figured that sticking to what I am good at would be the best way to go. I enjoy photography, it’s a passion of  mine. I’m also what you’d call a social butterfly, so the two tend to go hand in hand.

During the current lockdown situation and the governments advice on social distancing I wanted to somehow document this on my one walk of the day, but also being productive. I'd like the opportunity to photograph you and your family from a safe distance, on your doorstep, pulling stupid faces at the windows, maybe doing cartwheels in the garden, what ever you're up for. And for just £5 you get a couple of photos to remind you of a time you're unlikely to ever forget and the Mid Cheshire Foodbank gets 100% of that fee. This isn't about work, more about keeping active and helping out. Thank you so much for your support and I hope to see you on my rounds. Much love to you all, Adam xx

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my SECOND Just Giving page. With your help I have already raised over £500 for one Food charity; I would love to repeat that again this time for the Black Country Foodbank. 

Hello my name is Dillon and I am a student at Haberdashers Adams Grammar School. Like you I am worried about the effect Covid-19 is having on us all. I have seen on the news that many people are struggling with work meaning that they may not be able to buy food for their families and that is something I want to personally help with. I have done a charity car wash in my local area but now want to do something even bigger. 

So, I have decided to change the colour of my hair in support of the NHS. I am going to dye my hair in NHS Blue to show my appreciation for all the amazing work they are doing for us. All of the money raised will be used to buy as much food as possible. I hope that you will all support me in this worthwhile cause. 

I have already raised over £500 for another foodbank charity called The Trussell Trust; I would now like to provide the same help and support to Black Country Foodbank. I know that if we all come together we can not only achieve this goal but smash it.

Finally, please do keep looking back at this page for updates and pictures and don't forget to share with your family, friends and work colleagues.

Title: Lewisham Food Bank

Description:
What is good food?

  • No takeaway 
  • No greasy, fatty, fried or sugary food including candy, fizzy drinks, cake, ice cream, sausages (oh god), bacon (man what are you doing to yourself) or and I cant believe I am saying it but melted/american cheese.
  • Must contain minimum of two veg or fruit (I will have to google what this is but i'm sure I can get some somewhere) 

To some of you this will seem trivial, silly or just plain stupid but to those of you that know me (well you probably thought I was describing myself) I am known and have been known for a long time as having the worst diet of anyone people know. Today I had macaroni and cheese with bacon two ways, fried onion and egg for breakfast followed by a burger king double rodeo burger with fries and 9 chicken nuggets for lunch and dinner will consist of pizza, garlic bread and Camembert just to give you a picture of the scale of the problem we are dealing with here. Knowing me I will also likely have a small (not so small) bowl of Crave at around 11pm just to ensure I don't get hungry during the night. 

What if you cheat? How will we know?

  1. When at work I will be having my breakfast and lunch in the office so I can be observed. 
  2. Each meal I will photograph as evidence 
  3. I will be stabbed each day at the same time! By this I mean I will have my sugar levels check each and every day of the month before work having taken an average reading over the next 5 days to prove I haven't cheated when I get home. I will also photograph these results on weekends and maintain the pictures as proof. 

Why should I care?..........1,000,000+ People!

Simple answer really people are starving! Over 1 million people now rely on food banks in the UK in order to survive in this country. Now....just take that in for a minute; in one of the worlds top 10 economies we are allowing more and more people every year to fall through the net, these are children, adults, elderly, poor and sick people who are already suffering from poverty in a top 10 economy! 

So even if you don't care about the reason I am doing this think about the cause! Even £2.50 can provide enough ingredients to allow 1 person to attend an eat well for less course. Just £10 can help provide food for a whole family in need! 

For me? 

This is hard! Some of you will run, cycle, climb or jump off something for charity and I applaud you for it.......but this is something that will affect me every minute of every day. I haven't changed my diet in 15 years. If it was easy I would have done it already!

Finally entertainment:

You sadistic people will no doubt enjoy the selfies of misery, daily stabbing I will endure and joy of eating a burger king right under my nose so give what you can and lets see how much we can raise and don't forget every few ££s we raise will mean someone in our community is not going to bed hungry! 

Thanks!

Josh

Title: Ross's Shaving for the first time in 8 years

Description:
There are lots of things we will miss about rowing this summer: training with our friends; getting an awesome AIO tan; the excitement of racing and representing our college! But there is one tiny bonus, and that is we will save a bit of money through not taking part in races next term. So we have decided as a club, why not do some good with that instead? We would like to encourage our members, if able, to donate the cost of a post training brunch, or a race entry fee, or a celebratory beer, and together we can raise some funds for the Cambridge City Food Bank. 

Last year Cambridge City Food Bank provided 9,243 3- day emergency food supplies to families in crisis across Cambridge. With the current Covid-19 situation, that need is undoubtably only going to increase. For more information on the vital work this group does please visit https://cambridgecity.foodbank.org.uk
Title: HHBC fundraiser for Cambridge City Food Bank

Description:
On Sunday 5th April following cancellation of the Manchester Marathon my husband Brian Carroll ran amazing 105 laps around our 400m street loop covering his marathon distance. This inspired us to organise the Philips Walk and Wynd Ultra Marathon Relay for residents and fundraise for Hamilton District Foodbank raising money for those who may be in need during these challenging times.

On Easter Sunday starting  from 8am in 30 mins slots, 25  households, one household at a time, participants will walk/run/jog/scoot/bike around our 400m loop as many times as possible until 8:30pm in the evening. We expect to cover an ultramarathon distance of approx 40 miles. 

We would very much appreciate any donation however large or small  to help the local foodbank/community. 

Thank you very much for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Everyone hates burpees. Fact. What began as a challenge between friends we hope can turn into something good that can raise funds for the Lewisham food bank who are doing amazing things to look after the most vulnerable in our local community.

So, we have set ourselves the challenge of doing 1,000 burpees (each) in a day. It won’t be easy but hopefully knowing we are making a difference to those who need it most during these tough times will get us through!

The Lewisham food bank is part of a network of over 400 food banks, working to tackle food poverty and hunger in our local community, as well as across the UK. They provide food to those in need - something of particular importance as we fight the current Coronavirus. 

We hope our efforts will help raise funds for the food bank and awareness of all the good they are doing within our local community. Any donations would be very much appreciated!

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Baker Hughes JustGiving page.

To challenge ourselves and also support our local community we are setting out on a journey..

The aim collectively as a team, we will walk, run or cycle the equivalent distance from Newcastle upon Tyne to Sao Paulo via Houston and Niteroi, linking our 4 sites, over 16,000 kilometers. 

NCL to Houston - 7566 Km

Houston to Niteroi - 8085 Km

Niteroi to Sao Paulo - 386 Km

Locally we are already supporting the NHS by donating PPE so we wanted to support a worthy local foodbank which is located not far from our Newcastle Site as they need all the support we can give them during this difficult time.

The challenge is open to all and you can log your distance via the survey link here  http://surveys.ge.com/create/500122  add as many times as you like.

Thanks so much for your efforts and support.

Andy Mason

Description:
All is not well in the North Pole...

Santa was planning a holiday in the sun but he's been stranded in Northwich. So is going to try something to bring a little cheer - a summer sleigh ride!

As a trial run Santa will visit Weaverham this (20/6) afternoon and, if successful, will try to visit other areas in the near future too.

Santa asks that, if you're able, you donate some money to the fine people at Mid-Cheshire Foodbank using this page and in your donation message let us know your area (e.g. Rudheath, Castle, Barnton, etc).

As Mrs Claus is stuck looking after the elves she would love you to post photos below of Santa if you see him.

Santa is a very socially responsible chap so must insist that:
- You do not break social distancing rules - Santa would be sad if he caused upset to the fine people of Cheshire Police
- Santa, Rudolph, or any elves will not accept cash or other donations (but would love for you to donate via the link above)
- We won't be publishing a route or timings to prevent gatherings, please don't ask as we won't tell
- You don't travel from outside the area
- The sleigh will not stop
- Santa sadly won't be able to meet face to face
- keep 2m away from the vehicle

Rudolph is already unhappy about not having a summer off - please don't give him an excuse to put his foot down & leave.

If you'd like to know more about Round Table and what we do, please get in touch via facebook: 
https://www.facebook.com/northwichroundtable

Description:
CAN comedy have taken on the mission to raise money for this very worthwhile course.

Throughout December will be be raising funds at all our gigs as well as making a contribution ourselves to ensure we can do our bit to stop families in hardship going hungry this Christmas 

Black Country Food Bank helps vulnerable individuals and families in

crisis through the provision of 3 days emergency food supplies while a
longer-term solution is developed. The services we provide have an enormous
impact on the people who use them, giving them an important breathing space at
a time of great need.

Started in June 2006, we are a Christian-based

charitable organisation set up to feed local people experiencing real hardships
by meeting their most basic need for food. Local people, churches and other
organisations in and around the Black Country are joining together to be part
of a project that makes a real difference to the lives of those in crisis.

Description:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  

I have huge respect for my Muslim colleagues who work hard while fasting during Ramadan.  Ramadan is a time to reflect, pray and get involved in charitable giving donating through donating time and money.  Fasting is very difficult but this will be an opportunity to think about people who don't have easy access to food.

I'm raising money for a cause who tackle feelings of hunger and poverty felt by local people each day. Manchester Central Foodbank who provide three days’ nutritionally balanced emergency food and support to local people who are referred to them in crisis. They are part of a nationwide network of foodbanks, supported by The Trussell Trust, working to combat poverty and hunger across the UK.

Please donate what you can.  Think about what you would have spent on lunch:

  • One day - £3
  • Two days - £6
  • Working week - £15
  • Month - £60
